I suggest to ministers and to government members that that is a damning indictment of what you are doing. The Australian Democrats accept choice being made available to parents for the education of their children and for government funds being provided for this purpose. The Australian Democrats do not, however, accept that the consequence of choice should be cuts in state school grants. By all means, advance the private schools if you wish, but not at the expense of state schools.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have experience of the school system across Australia, so I am going to focus on Western Australia. These are the problems in Western Australian state schools for which more money is needed, not less. The real state outlay per student in state schools has been falling. By 2001, WA schools will need to accommodate an extra 65,000 students. Class sizes need to be drastically reduced, for instance, from the current 32 in primary schools to 25 at least. WA has the third highest class numbers after New South Wales and Queensland.

More support is needed in classes where students with disabilities are integrated. The Court government is making schools sell their grounds to pay for capital expenditure. Attracting good teachers to the country is a real problem. To implement the Tomlinson report on schooling in rural WA needs money. In technology, New South Wales and Queensland commit $135 million over four years for the computer acquisition scheme in state schools. In WA, it is $6 million for a year. School maintenance needs an additional $250 million over the next five years. That is just a short list of why WA needs more money.

Greater problems in WA schools because of less money, fewer teachers, worse maintenance and poor pupil‐teacher ratios are answered by Premier Court—how?—by his saying `Bring back the cane. Put the kids in uniform and march them around as cadets.' That is really imaginative!

Senator Kernot and others in the earlier debate on state grants made it clear that the premiers rolled over to the Commonwealth on state grant reductions. Our plea as the Australian Democrats is that that trend be reversed.

In our view, the future depends on investment in two areas and, to use the economic parlance, that investment should be on capital and labour. On capital, the government has launched the biggest anti-business package this country could ever have imagined. On labour, our schools and universities are under attack. Money is needed to invest in a secure and productive future. Schools and state grants for schools are part of that.

The necessary cooperation and coordination of investment into our future between state and Commonwealth ministers has been grossly inadequate. The movement of the onus from the public to the private school and from the public purse to the private pocket will be found in future years to be just not smart. It is just not good policy.

PARA.BREAK: Mr Clinton could just as easily have talked about intellectual capital as intellectual prop erty. The government and the country are underinvesting now in capital and labour, which is making matters worse, and are therefore discounting our future. It is for that reason that I have strong concerns about the bill and its policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996. It is important in this debate to distil fact from rhetoric. In his second reading speech, and this passage is quoted in the majority report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee, the minister said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The bill fulfils the government's commitments to promote excellence and achievement through the provision of quality education and prepare our young people for an active and productive life both in the work force and as participating citizens in the community and global economy. The bill fosters a partnership approach with states and territories which recognises both the constitutional responsibility of states and territories for education and the Commonwealth's role in guiding national directions and priorities.
I pause there to say that the states do not agree with that. The states, with the exception of Victoria and the territories, have serious concerns about this bill, and I will come back to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of this bill is quite different from the passage that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) relied upon. Under the smokescreen of choice, this bill has the potential to strip significant funding from the government school sector; to destroy the orderly regulatory system of the schools in Australia, and I am talking about primary and secondary schools; to reignite the divisive state aid debate; to provoke retaliatory state government action to reduce state funding of government schools; to exacerbate the literacy problems in the community by reducing funding to the government school sector, the sector with primary responsibility for the disadvantaged sectors of the community; and to dramatically alter the ratio of government and non-government schools.

There are many elements to this bill. I want to deal predominantly with the abolition of Labor's new schools policy and with the establishment of the enrolment benchmark adjustment measure to determine the proportion of expenditure going to government as against non-government schools, and obviously vice versa. On the issue of the abolition of the new schools policy, the rhetoric which underlies the approach was expressed by Senator Tierney, who in the committee hearings consistently referred to Labor's new schools policy as the no new schools policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No new schools policy.

—Thank you very much, Senator Tierney. The evidence really does portray that statement as utter nonsense. It shows that 251 additional, new schools in the non-government sector have been established and funded. On the evidence that the committee received, there are also quite a number of schools which have been set up irrespective of funding. That is the decision that they wanted to take. That has always been open to them.

SPEECH.PARA: We look at what Senator Tierney has been saying, and we have to say that the evidence just does not back it up. That is what I said at the start of this speech, Senator Tierney—this debate has been marked by a lot of rhetoric. We need to look at the facts. That was the rhetoric, unfortunately, that the government used, leading up to the elections, to justify this policy—the statement that Labor's policy was of no new schools. Arrant nonsense! You know it, Senator Tierney, so does the community, so do the non-government schools.

With all of the evidence that we receive—notwithstanding that they wanted more funding, that they would like to have open slather—they have to concede that there has been plenty of funding for the non-government sector. The evidence is plain—251 new schools, Senator Tierney. So let us debunk the nonsense and the rhetoric that has been the basis of this policy and underlies this bill.

The new schools policy became, in effect, a real regulator of the enmeshing of the educational institutions throughout Australia in the primary and secondary schools area. We have seen and heard at the committee stage of the bill, and it was also mentioned in debate in the House of Representatives, that a very minimal regulatory system exists within the states with regard to the establishment of new schools—very minimal. Most of the states, in fact, have no regard to whether, for example, a new school is being set up next door to an existing school, government or non-government. But the new schools policy did have regard to that.

This bill proposes to eradicate that and to basically say to the states, `It all falls back on you. You make the decision.' The evidence is that there is not the basis for proper regulation in the states. This policy and this bill will create chaos in the states in relation to this matter.

It is fair to say that even the government members of the committee are uneasy about the demise of the policy—even though they might not want to admit it. You have only to look at their first recommendation, which basically says that there should be a mechanism, which could take the form of restructured new schools committees or joint planning committees, which would need to be representative, accessible and open to public scrutiny. They are saying, `Yes, there are deficiencies. The bill does not deal with them. Something has to be done, and this is a recommendation we make.'

So the government members of the committee who reviewed this bill, even though they had to be loyal to their party's position to pursue this legislation, have to say, `There are some matters we are uneasy about, so we will make a recommendation and maybe it will all go away.' That is not good enough. How ill considered this bill must be if those government members of the committee are making recommendations which effectively reveal such a gaping hole in the bill.

In another passage of the report, on page 25, the government members recognise another implication. In talking about aspects of the bill which might constrain the expansion of the non-government sector, they say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The State, of course, will retain 50% of the savings—
capital savings—

for use . . . but it might be expected that under such arrangements States will consider, perhaps more seriously than they have before, the implications for government enrolments of the establishment of a non-government school.

So what are they saying? They are recognising what was revealed in evidence, which is that perhaps some states will say, `We now have to take some action to haul things back to suit ourselves, so we will make things harder for the non-government schools to establish to protect our funding base.' That is what you must draw from that passage in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The government members of the committee themselves are concerned that there is a possible unintended consequence. It might be good for this government to say, `It is not our fault; it is the state government, go to them,' when there are problems in the states. But the reality is that this bill is removing an existing regulatory mechanism, effectively throwing it open to the free market. Their own committee is saying that there is another problem, and it might be that someone else takes a hand and becomes the regulatory body.

In fact, the states may have a vested interest in regulating against the establishment of more new schools just so that they can protect the revenue base that supports the government school sector. It might not happen in every state, and it might not happen tomorrow, but they are recognising that this is a distinct possibility. So maybe the states will and maybe the states will not, but is that a risk that a good policy‐making bill should take? I suggest not.

That is a topic which, if it does arise, is certainly going to arouse the passions of those on both sides in this debate. Whether they like to admit it or not—and they did hear plenty of evidence about this matter from quite a number of people, both from the government side of the debate and from the non‐government side of the debate—this bill has the potential to re‐create the state aid debate. So it is quite disingenuous to suggest that that is not a reality, that is, that the possibility is not there for this debate to be re‐created.

On the subject of the abolition of the new schools policy, the committee received submissions for and against the abolition of that policy. You could argue that the various points of view came from parties with vested interests in one or other of the outcomes that are possible with the passage or denial of passage of this bill—that they were either wedded to or opposed to the new schools policy because the outcome one way or the other benefited them. For example, certain of the non‐government school sectors would see that they had a much greater chance to expand their sector under this bill. Certainly, those who supported the government sector saw a great threat to the government sector and were supportive of the new schools policy because they saw it as a responsible regulatory measure for the system.

There is one submission which I would put to the Senate is able to be set apart from the others on that issue with regard to the new schools policy. That submission came from the Independent Education Union, which represents teachers and others in the non‐government school sector. They are reputed to be the fastest growing union in this country because of their enrolments in the growing sector which, since 1985, has grown from 24.4 per cent of enrolments to something in excess of 29 per cent. Naturally, there has been an increase in the number of teachers involved. They had positive things to say about the new schools policy. At the bottom of page 57 of the minority report—I will not read the whole passage—they are quoted as saying:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The operation of the new schools policy has, in our view, been to minimise that.
They are talking about the problem with establishing schools in the non‐government school sector that were not viable. They continue:

I would point to the kind of experience that we had with schools in the period 1980 to 1986 . . . Over time, a good number of those schools floundered and the community disquiet about all of that is what led to the inquiry that ended up with the new schools policy . . .

They did not have a vested interest in opposing this bill because the sector that they represent, it is suggested, will grow. Therefore, their potential to enrol members will grow. They were quite open and candid about that. But they were also, to their credit, prepared to say, `We have to recognise the very positive aspects about the new schools policy and we really don't think that it is a wise move to jettison it in the environment that we will be going into vis‐a‐vis lack of proper regulation elsewhere.'

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the enrolment benchmark adjustment. Senator Carr in the minority report dealt with that fairly well. I think the states, it must be said, are almost unanimous in their depiction of this policy as misplaced and illogical. Government members of the committee want us to pass the bill, yet even they were not convinced of the logic of the bill in relation to this funding sharing mechanism. You have only to look at their own recommendation, which is the second recommendation by government members of the committee. They do not want to do anything to the bill, and I would not have expected that they would recommend that. No doubt they would be loyal to their party position in relation to the bill. But they recommended that the department—and I quote:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . undertake immediately a round of detailed consultations with the State and Territory governments in relation to the anticipated savings arising from the Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment, and report to the Minister on the outcome of those consultations as soon as possible.

Why is that recommendation necessary? Why doesn't the bill contemplate that? If that is a matter that has to be properly considered, why is this bill being rushed through now? Why isn't that a matter on which there has been much greater consultation? There has been a lot of criticism in the community and also at a government level about the lack of consultation in relation to this measure. So they are saying, `Pass the bill but rely on the minister to consult the state and territory governments.' And do what? What is the minister going to do? Is he going to rush back here and amend the legislation if it is wrong? Is that the suggestion that the committee is making? If they are not convinced, why should the Senate and the public be convinced? It is too big a question to be left unanswered. If this measure is not needed until the 1998 funding year, why rush and pass it now?

BREAK.PARA: In relation to my own state of Tasmania, it is very clear that the Tasmanian government is concerned about the enrolment benchmark adjustment measure in terms of the funding ramifications for the state. It is also concerned about the lack of consultation. We are talking about a government that is of the same political persuasion as this government. So it is not a case of simply being partisan to a party point of view. This is the view of one of the number of Liberal state governments who are concerned about this legislation, who want more consultation and who are concerned about the financial ramifications of this bill. Again, we are being asked to rush through and deal with this matter quickly.

In Tasmania, there are 29 non‐government schools funded under the current legislation. Three of those schools are not fully funded and they will benefit from the passage of this legislation. I intend to deal with Senator Abetz's challenge shortly, and I will deal with that very point. There are three other schools that are not funded and yet operate. In relation to the current policy, it certainly has not been a barrier to the establishment or the functioning of the non-government school sector in the state of Tasmania.

I was going to refer to the evidence of Mr Graham Speight, the Principal of Bridgewater High School. That is in the table of evidence at page 157. He indicates the concerns of the government school sector, particularly as to the potential impact on a very important school in a disadvantaged area in Tasmania with a growing student number. I think the reality is that, if this bill passes, that school and schools like it will suffer. I can only, to try to deal with my remarks in the time permitted, abbreviate my comments in that regard.

This matter is too important to be rushed through, and this bill is too important to be rushed through intact. The Labor opposition will be moving a number of amendments to the bill during the committee stage. Unless they succeed, the Senate will have effectively ignored the concerns of the states and many in the community. There have been a great many submissions opposing this bill. We will be passing into law a very dubious, very unsound and very dangerous piece of legislation.

I come now to the challenge Senator Abetz put to me to make some comments. Firstly, I would have to categorise his representation of the new schools policy as a gross misrepresentation. Frankly, to suggest that there was opposition to the funding of the various religious and ethnic groups and that that is why there was opposition to the bill is to grossly misrepresent the position that is taken not just by Senator Allison and the Democrats but also by the overwhelming majority, if not all, of the people who oppose this bill. I remind Senator Abetz that if he looks at the list of schools that are now funded under Labor's policy he will find that the schools that fall into all the categories he mentioned, whether they be fundamentalist Christian, Jewish or whatever, are able to be funded under the same guidelines as apply to every other group in the community.

As to his reference to the Kingston Christian and Circular Head Schools, I think Senator Abetz has challenged me to justify why they are not funded. They are not funded because they do not meet those tests. If the tests need to be amended, then perhaps that is the way to go. I remind him that there are government schools that have closed because funding has not been available to support the number of schools existing in that sector. He referred to a school with 40 pupils. That school will no doubt be in a remote area, not in the areas in which the private schools operate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996 as a government member of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee. This bill attempts to fulfil the government's election commitments to education. It puts in place a four-year commitment to basic resources for schools. Most importantly, it widens the options for parents to choose the most appropriate school for their children.

PARA.BREAK: The legislation also reflects the government's commitments to providing a quality school education system for Australian stu dents, wherever they choose to attend a school. It contains additional funding for literacy and for school‐to‐work programs to ensure that when students leave school they are properly prepared to gain real jobs. It contains funding for a languages program. It contains funding for a special learning needs program. The broadbanding, which has reduced the number of targeted programs from 40 to five, still services the needs of specific client groups who are educationally disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The new literacy strategy is an important and long overdue improvement to our education system. Currently, one in five children leaves school with literacy and numeracy problems. Indeed, an article in one of this morning's newspapers commented that if children cannot read and numerate well by the time they reach about grade 3 and 4 in the primary school system it is highly likely that those children will leave school with those problems never being addressed. Certainly, the national schools English literacy survey, the results of which will be released next year, will establish benchmarks as to the way in which governments should target funding to address this very important national concern. It is this government's policy that both literacy and numeracy should have the first call on the education dollar. This bill commits funding of $45 million over the next three years, from 1997 to 1999, to this strategy.

There has been a great deal of comment in this debate on government versus non-government schools. As Senator Tierney did, I point out that over the next four years government is estimated to increase funding per student in a government school by 17.9 per cent and for a student in a non-government school by 14.92 per cent. Contrary to claims that the bill will lead—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your evidence for that?

—From the minister's office, Senator Carr. Contrary to claims that the bill will lead to an unrestricted growth in non‐government schools, it is anticipated that the proportion of students in non-government schools will increase by less than three per cent over the next three years.
—How do you know that?
—This was borne out in evidence put before the committee. Senator Carr, are you disputing the evidence put forward by witnesses?
—Absolutely.
—For instance, Dr Tannock from the National Catholic Education Commission said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I do not think that the abolition of the new schools . . . will make much difference to what has been happening. . . .

[There] is not a vast, pent up demand for new non-government school places . . . If there were, . . . I would hope and expect that the state governments would exercise their responsibility for planned educational provision and ensure it did not happen.
Dr Tannock also said:
I do not think [the non-government sector] will grow rapidly . . . I do not know how far it would go but I would be very surprised if it went up to more than 35 per cent.

Over the next four years government schools will receive an additional $2.3 billion from Commonwealth sources and that is through this bill and financial assistance grants. As I said, funding for students in government schools will increase by 17.9 per cent. Funding for students in non-government schools will increase by 14.92 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to comment on the new schools policy in this way: since the election I have opened many extensions to non-government schools for the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp). At those schools I have been received with open arms as a representative of a government that has lifted the restrictions on new schools that were placed on it by the former federal government. In fact, that policy failed because the proportion of students in non-government schools increased from 26.4 per cent in 1986 to 29.4 per cent this year.

That policy discriminated against low income families, far from the stereotype that is presented by the opposition of non-government schools as those being exclusively the preserve of the rich. Every single one of the schools at which I have opened extensions belonged to low income families who have a keen interest and a stake in providing quality education for their students whether they choose to enrol them at a government school or a non-government school. That puts paid to the opposition's claims to represent the battler.

This government intends to abolish the failed new schools policy by 1997. Overall funds from the Commonwealth in 1996 provide $2,263 per student in government schools and $2,405 for students in non-government schools. There is additional funding for government schools provided by the states.

Lastly, I would like to move to the issue of choice. Senator O'Brien I think referred in his remarks to the issue of choice being a smokescreen. On the contrary, the issue of choice is one of the fundamental educational principles embodied in the constitution and the way in which educational practice has grown up in this country. Parents should have choice.
The committee report talked about choice for parents. I refer particularly to the comments by Mr Rockman of the Australian Coordinating Committee of Jewish Day Schools. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: We would believe that any group in the community who wishes to operate a school and who meet appropriate criteria, can provide appropriate education, should be permitted to do so.
We have diversity—
This is always a principle that is being mentioned by the opposition and the Democrats—

in virtually all other areas of life in this community. We have it in education, we have it in sport, we have it right across the areas of consumer choice and so on. We do not see that education should be singled out as an area where there ought not be diversity.

BREAK.PARA: Similarly, I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to an article in this morning's Australian entitled `Why state schools are my choice' by journalist Deborah Hope. That article is subtitled `In the debate about private versus public education, tradition doesn't always win'. The journalist goes on to emphasise the choice that she and her family made between a government or a non-government school. She emphasised that the choice was one that they made for a variety of reasons.

Choice is paramount in this article and choice is something that we should be promoting. She promotes the excellence of government schools, which is fine and that is the choice that parents make. There are many excellent government schools. By the same token, there are many excellent non-government schools. That is a choice that every parent makes on the basis of factors which they take into consideration. I might add that Ms Hope finishes the article by saying:
And the money that we would otherwise be pouring into school fees will be going into family travel. Next stop Indonesia.

She chooses to make that choice because she has chosen government schools over non-government schools. Similarly, many parents make the choice of a non-government school over a government school. That is something that should be borne in mind in this debate.

This bill is, above everything, finding the right balance in education. It is about providing opportunities for all young Australians pursuing an education whether they be in government or non-government schools. The government values and intends to support the valuable contribution made by both systems to educating Australians and preparing them for the future. It is tangible proof of the government's commitment to government and non-government schools in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill. In particular, it is a very clear bill that has a very unclear policy shrouded underneath it, that is, the privatisation of education by stealth. It is a clear shift of dollars from the public sector to the private sector. The most important thing that the government has run by way of arguing against this is to say that those on this side who want to argue the way I want to argue are opposed to private schools. Nothing could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Labor government established the new schools policy to try to make sense of exactly the sorts of concerns that the government now claim are highest in their priority. The Labor government did not want to see new schools springing up all over the place that clearly did not have sufficient numbers to remain viable or sufficient numbers to provide the children attending those schools with an adequate and proper range of educational opportunities. It is precisely because of the Labor government's commitment to an adequate alternative provision of private schooling options for people that they established the new schools policy. There is absolutely no clear guidelines or policy from this Howard government for why it wants to abolish the new schools policy.

There is no clear evidence that the new schools policy has disadvantaged people. There is no well‐documented evidence that the new schools policy has done serious harm to the private sector. There is no evidence that children attending those schools, as instituted under the new schools policy, were given anything other than a reasonable education.

In the years prior to that, there was a lot of evidence that private schools that started willy‐nilly, or with very small numbers of students, certainly got into major trouble and became a significant call or drain on both the state and the Commonwealth for continued funding. The new schools policy was established to make sense and give assurance to the people choosing those options that they would continue to have the reasonable and viable education alternative for their children.

There is another important point here. If this government were able to proceed with abolishing the new schools policy—and I do not know that it is clear in this chamber that they will be able to, but let us say they do—when and by what criteria are they going to come back into this place and say, `We got it wrong'? They have actually made sure that it is not necessarily going to be the case because they have said, `We will be shifting funding from the public sector to the private sector.'

Senator Abetz came in here with one of those marvellously spurious arguments, `You're hopeless. You're wrong. We're giving more money to the private schools and we're giving more money to the public schools.' You can say what you like, Senator Abetz, but this whole bill is based on a shift. There may be more money to both sectors, but there is a direct shift of dollars from the public sector to the private sector, contingent on those enrolments increasing in the private area.

Why would you want to do that? Why would you want to cut money away from the public sector? Those of us who stand on this side in opposition to this bill should note, to our some time discomfort perhaps, that we are joined in our opposition to this bill by the premiers of the states of this nation, many of whom would not stand with me on just about any policy at all! They are furious about the consequences to them, of what will happen in their states as a result of this reduction in public funding.

Senator Troeth was claiming that, under the constitution, there is a right to choice in this country. Senator Carr said, `Show us where.' It would be hard to find it, but there is clear evidence, which I have sought and had provided, before a current inquiry of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee, which I chair, that in the constitution of every state in this country there is a bill and a promise for free secular education for our children—in other words, our public schooling system. That is enshrined in the laws and the guarantees of the states on behalf of the children of this country.

Those states are very concerned about how they will continue their commitment to free secular education. The inquiry we are actually conducting at the moment is about private funding for public schools. The public schools cannot continue on the current funding. Indeed, most states are now defining free education to refer to the salaries of teachers and some capital grants. But, if you are asking for the funding of chalk, textbooks, pigeon holes or lots of other bits and pieces that go necessarily with education, that is no longer being defined—usually by regulation or some kind of edict from the governments—as the core part of the promise of free education.

More and more parents are being required to pay fees for free education. They are called voluntary contributions. The word `voluntary' is often dropped from the advice to parents about their contribution. We hear stories and read about them daily in the newspapers of parents who are being pressured. In one of the major dailies—and I cannot quote the place, I do not have it with me here—there was a report about one child who said, `My parents were told they would not be able to attend my speech day break‐up unless they came up with my voluntary contribution.' Schools subsequently rushed to deny it, but the evidence before our committee of inquiry has been that all over the country there is pressure on parents to make the payment of those voluntary contributions. Schools are not being provided with sufficient funding through the states or the Commonwealth at the moment to provide what any of them would call a satisfactory free secular education.

In my own state of South Australia, there is now provision for schools, the boards of the schools, the parents association, or whichever is the body approved in that school to make the decision, to make decisions about the sale of land on which the school is sited. Fifty per cent of the money from the sale of that land will be returned to the state, but 50 per cent will be retained by the schools to assist with their further and continuing costs.

One organisation from Queensland is now going around to the public schools in South Australia trying to buy land on which it will build a private child-care centre. As I said before, 50 per cent of the money from the sale of that land will be retained by the school to enable them to continue to provide what they regard as being sufficient, adequate or necessary for free secular education.

In one place, the child-care centres in the neighbourhood of that school heard about this proposal and attended the meeting. They were so persuasive in pointing out the number of child-care centres around that school and that a further one at the school was absolutely unnecessary and would only guarantee the failure of all the centres that, in the end, the school decided not to proceed that way.

Now what is happening when schools are having to go to these lengths to find sufficient funding? They are certainly not going to be assisted by this piece of legislation, which says that if students move from the public sector to the private sector, a lot of the dollars will go with them. That is not going to help state governments deliver free secular education. It is certainly not going to help the states to continue under the current financial constraints that they bear and which they have made extremely clear to the Howard government. These involve cuts to untied grants—the financial assistance grants—to the states of $1.5 billion over three or four years. I believe that one senator in here today estimated that it would mean at least $400 million out of state education—that is if the states continue their commitment to education on the current arrangements.

I urge people to look at the dissenting report of the legislation committee on this bill, because it points out that one way the government is obfuscating with the figures is by rolling in the financial assistance grants, or FAGs. I will read a paragraph from that report:

The Labor and Australian Democrat Senators note with interest that, although the States Grants Bill deals with the allocation of Specific Purpose Payments to States, the Commonwealth's submission to this Committee, and the Minister's arguments elsewhere, insist on the inclusion of attributed levels of Financial Assistance Grants throughout the Commonwealth's justification and explanation of its funding proposals.

There are lots of concerns. One is that the states will continue to provide something like a 24 or 25 per cent share of FAGs to education. It is also important to note that those so-called FAGs grants now include road grants of something approaching $400 million and will pass $400 million by the year 2000. That is a significant distortion of the total FAGs money that might be available to the states, from which you could ascribe 25 per cent to education. Take out the road funding first before you do that.

What we have is a significant cut of money directly to the states. We have now got a clear statement that, for the enrolments to private schools, the funding for the public schools will be reduced. It is a simple proposal. It is actually all part of allowing anybody who wants to establish a private school to do so, with the only real restriction on their opportunity to do that being registered with the state.

The arguments are very clear. State registration might be adequate for some sorts of assessments, such as the ongoing viability of the school and the capacity of the school to provide an adequate education and so on, but it certainly does nothing for the adequate placement of our schools in this country or the overall planning requirement for the distribution of Commonwealth, let alone state, dollars for schools. It is a certain move away from the brakes, checks and balances that allow the proper allocation of both Commonwealth and state dollars to education.

Nobody in this place is standing up and arguing against private or public schools. If anybody says that I am, let them say it to my face in here or outside and I will make it clear that that is not what I and rest of the opposition are saying. The opposition is saying that it objects strenuously to removing the new schools policy, with its balances, program and planning, and allowing people to establish a private school with nothing more than state registration. There is now no coherent proposal or planning possible under that kind of arrangement.

Worse is the concurrent removal of money from the public sector to the private sector. The comments of Senator Murray earlier today are also very useful. Again, I say on behalf of the opposition that we do not object to private schools. Indeed, look at the history of the Labor Party's contribution to sorting out the debate between public and private schools, sometimes short handed to the expression `state aid' in times past. Labor governments have done so much to contribute to the balanced provision of public and private schooling. This bill blows apart that coherence.

I ask the minister how he will know when this is not going well. What criteria does he have that will highlight when public schools are underfunded to the point of becoming unviable? Most public schools around this country are already screaming for more funds. They are seeking outside private funding to enable them to continue what they call basic level funding. Schools have told us that some of their private funding goes to pay recurrent costs, particularly teachers' salaries, and that state governments are managing to obfuscate their books by not being totally honest about actual recurrent funding for teachers.

We will continue to take evidence on these very serious matters in our Senate inquiry. Nobody around Australia says that schools are so flush with dollars that they are happy to see any shift in allocations. They are not. They are struggling very much to provide the sorts of things that the parents of Australia want. The parents of Australia are asking, `If we are having free secular education through our public schools, how come we are paying and being asked to pay more and more each year by way of voluntary contributions or fees?'

Funding to our public sector schools is not adequate. That is the consistent report from all over Australia. As honourable senators would have read, schools in various places have toyed with varieties of sponsorships. We have had proposals from chains, such as McDonalds and others, to start providing assistance to schools. Most education departments have worked out that they are not satisfactory provisions. Some state systems are looking at ways in which they can be assisted by private contributions and not in any way jeopardise the independence or quality of schooling provided. They are very major concerns about the adequacy of funding. Allowing new schools to emerge with no coherent planning and with no more than the requirement of state registration is moving very clearly in the opposite direction of coherence and best planned support for our schools.

Again, I ask—I am sure it is a question I asked rhetorically before and forgot to finish pursuing—what criteria does the minister have for when this proposal will need to be reined in? What criteria will we have when there are too many too small schools or is this a case of saying, `Oh, well, the states can manage that; they'll be approving the registration. If it blows up, it will blow up in the states' face and the Commonwealth will be clean'? That is a very nice policy if you can pull it off. But I do not believe that the community will be fooled any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are a cynic, its a nice policy.

—Thank you, Senator Carr. Indeed, if you are a cynic, you could settle for that. But this dispute between the Commonwealth and the states will not be assisted by this dramatic cut in funding and change in funding to the public sector. Thousands of people do choose the public sector for their children but, more importantly, we know that even within the public sector there is a range of differences between the schools. If you visit the public sector schools in our western suburbs, they are the schools which are much less likely to find sponsorship or private assistance for them to meet what they require and regard as necessary for adequate schooling to supplement the shortfall from the state and Commonwealth allocations.

SPEECH.PARA: Further run‐down in funding to our public sector schools will do nothing to advantage those schools already struggling. It will certainly not do anything to improve the quality of education for families in those areas where schools have to manage on the government allocations and almost nothing more. Many of the parents who attend those schools are not the parents who are flush with spare capital to make their so-called voluntary contributions. Those schools are struggling to meet the needs of their children. They are not assisted by any re‐allocation of funding, as this bill proposes.

This bill is taking an awful step. The biggest concern I have is that under the name of choice and in a very large educational policy vacuum, we have what is clearly a privatisation by stealth. No, it will not happen overnight and no, there will not be a rush to close public schools and open private ones, but the trend is established. The big tick for that kind of behaviour and that kind of movement is now written in law if this bill passes. That is what this bill is about. It is a move away from a commitment by the states to free secular education, adequate and sufficient and enabling of our children and our families, to blowing that apart and saying, `We will now see much more irregular—

TALK.START.PARA: —Deregulated.

—Deregulated, but I mean irregular emergence of schools. Many of them will not be sufficient to provide anything like the same adequate education for our children. The cost will be insufficient education in many of our public schools. If anyone doubts that, go check the scene in Victoria. In yesterday's Age there is a report that the retention rates that this Labor government had built up to 81 per cent are now falling significantly in the public schools and schools across Victoria. There are many thousands of schools closed in Victoria. There are teachers out of jobs. This bill will do nothing to supplement or support or recreate and commit to education the vital needs of the families of Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996. I support fully the remarks just made by Senator Crowley and earlier by Senator Carr and other Labor and Democrat speakers regarding the grave concerns that not only we have about this legislation but also the concerns felt by many people out there—parents, staff, students and organisations involved in public education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, this legislation is hasty, it is ill-considered, it has been brought in with a lack of consultation, it is ideologically motivated and it is potentially damaging not only to public education or the government education sector of this country but I believe, overall, to the quality of education in the future.

I would like to begin by quoting from the opening paragraphs of the dissenting report of the Senate Legislation Committee on Employment, Education and Training that looked at this legislation. In doing so, I congratulate Senators Carr, Crowley and Allison on what is a very thorough review of this legislation, albeit it having to be completed in a very short space of time given the undue haste with which the government has moved in this most important area of public policy—that of education. I quote from the introduction:

BREAK.PARA: The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996 represents a major shift in the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States with respect to the funding of education. Moreover, it heralds the first moves by the Commonwealth to abrogate key national responsibilities for ensuring an equitable and high quality schooling system in Australia.

For the past two decades the Commonwealth has assumed, for extremely good reasons, an important leadership role in promoting advances in the curriculum, teaching and infrastructure of Australia's schools, in both the government and the non-government sector. It has presided over an unprecedented rise in the number of students staying on at school beyond the compulsory years; the development and implementation of the National Goals for Schooling; dramatic improvements in the professional development opportunities for teachers; and the establishment of probably the most equitable schooling system in the world.
All of this is being put at risk by a government which is unwilling to bear its responsibility for the promotion of the national interest . . .

Those two paragraphs sum up superbly the grave concerns that we in the opposition, the Democrats and people involved in government education have regarding this legislation. What we are placing at risk with this legislation is a high quality equitable education system that has been developed in this country in the last 20 years or so, one which is characterised by the cooperative approach adopted in both non-government and government schools.

It is a hallmark of our school system that we have both a viable non‐government as well as government school system. We have an equitable education system and one which recognises choice already. I will make more comments about this issue of choice shortly. The system also recognises the fundamental responsibility of the national government—not just the state governments where primary responsibility lies—to provide education funding to both government and non‐government sectors. The system also recognises the role and responsibility of national government in ensuring equity across the nation, ensuring equality of opportunity across the nation and ensuring that all children, irrespective of socio‐economic status, will have access to high quality education in their schooling years.

This is something that cannot be achieved if you deregulate the system. If the national government abrogates that responsibility and simply leaves it to the states to once again treat education as something that may be a budgetary process for them from year to year, they will not take on board the need to look at national standards to ensure that children in all states have that equity and equality of opportunity.

We know that this was not always the case. Many of us can remember the divisive debate—and I recall that it was more than a debate—in the sixties over the issue of state aid and previous speakers have referred to that. It is important to recall that, because what we are placing at risk here is the cooperative spirit that has existed now for many years which put an end to that divisive debate in the sixties over whether or not government should provide support to the non‐government school sector. As one who was educated in a Catholic school, I recall how divisive that debate was within the community and within political parties, both Liberal and Labor. I pay tribute to previous Liberal governments and in particular to the Whitlam Labor government. I recall how we put an end to that division and said over the last two long periods of government—the Fraser years and then the Hawke and Keating governments—that we would never revisit that era.

The principles upon which the involvement of the national government in education is based are, firstly, cooperation with the states. It is based upon also the availability of choice to parents as to which system they wish to send their children into. It is also based upon ensuring that the role of government is to provide first and foremost a quality, universally available government school system and one which can in cooperation with non‐government school systems—particularly the Catholic systemic school system which is the largest non‐government school sector in the country—ensure that equity.

In this debate it is also important to remember that those who have chosen in the past and those who will choose in the future to send their children to non‐government schools have recognised that they make a contribution over and above that which applies to people at government schools. That has been willingly accepted. Therefore, in my view the issue of choice comes down to ensuring that the government is, firstly, providing adequate funding for the government school sector; secondly, providing a reasonable level of funding to the non‐government school sector so that that burden does not become onerous particularly upon parents who in many cases would be in low to medium income circumstances; and, thirdly, ensuring that both systems can develop in harmony for the betterment of education and for children generally.

I make those comments because it has never been my experience—both as a participant, a parent and someone who has been involved in the policy debate on education in this country—that people do not see the school systems as always being in direct competition. I am afraid that what we have in this legislation is an ideological motivation which deliberately intends to promote the non‐government school system at the expense of the government school sector. To my mind that represents an elitist view and that is clear from the comments made earlier in this debate by Senator Abetz. I make that comment because it is clear from the evidence that even those involved at the cutting edge of non‐government education in this country do not wish to see that polarisation.

For instance, Dr Tannock from the National Catholic Education Commission appeared before the committee. While I accept he did not necessarily accept all the aspects of the new school policy, he nevertheless drew attention to this very serious issue. He said that they do not wish to see an undermining of the cooperation and coordination in the policy framework which has been developed. I quote from his evidence on page 200. He said:

We supported the principle, implicit and explicit, in the previous new schools policy of so‐called planned educational provision. We think it is reasonable that, first of all, new non‐government schools should not start up unless they are demonstrably viable and unless their quality is assured. We also felt that it was reasonable to ask people to give due notice of intention to start a school and that it was also reasonable to have regard in the development of a new non‐government school to its potential impact on an existing school. That was our position, and that remains our position.

On page 202, Dr Tannock commented upon the situation in education in this country over the last 10 years. In answer to a question from Senator Carr regarding the enrolment benchmark adjustment and how it might affect the cooperative relationship, he said:
I would certainly hope not, and I would be very disturbed if it did.
These are the important words—

The National Catholic Education Commission has made it absolutely clear to both government and opposition that in general it regards the achievements of the last 10 years or more in the non‐government school funding area, where in essence the state aid issue has been settled in Australia, as a major milestone in Australia's social and educational history, and it would not want it to be reopened or revisited.

It is important to bear those observations in mind. They come from somebody in the non‐government school sector. When we hear the contributions of people like Senator Abetz and Senator Tierney, you would think that there were people out there right through the non‐government school sector demanding this legislation. That is not the case. It is well recognised—and the statistics prove it—that there has been a significant expansion of non‐government schools under the new schools policy. But it was done in a planned way.

When we were in government I had the opportunity on a number of occasions to represent the then minister, Ross Free, at non‐government school openings and government school openings. Sometimes I attended in tandem with the New South Wales minister. Schools in both sectors continually told me of their appreciation for what the then government was doing in education. Credit was given by schools in both sectors for the substantial amounts of money that were being put into the system. Credit was also given for the improvements and the policy direction. That record, of course, is substantial. In the 13 years of the Labor government we increased real levels of direct funding for schools by around 58 per cent. Retention rates doubled to 80 per cent. We implemented the national equity program for schools which targeted children in specific areas—literacy, numeracy, special assistance in the English language and vocational training—and people with disabilities.

What do we see now? We see a strategy which, quite clearly, seeks to promote the development of new schools in the non‐government sector without any real regard to the sorts of planning requirements that existed under the new schools policy—planning requirements accepted by the non‐government school sector, as I have said. The national equity program is essentially being reduced in its effectiveness. Rather than specific targeting, these programs will now be broadbanded. With that sort of approach, disadvantaged groups will inevitably suffer. Children will once again fall through the net. What do you get if you hand more of this sort of control back to the states? Variations in monitoring, and variations in the provision of this specific special education. As time goes on, it will not be possible to ensure that equity across the country.

I have another concern with regard to this legislation. Far from there being some massive increase in education spending, we are, in fact, seeing an overall reduction in the Commonwealth's contribution to government schools. We have seen a massive $1.5 billion reduction in financial assistance grants to the states. As it has been estimated that around 17 per cent of FAGs are spent on schools, that will result in a reduction of $250 million. Concurrently, decisions are being made—particularly by the coalition government in Victoria—to slash the provision of government school education. In Victoria, over 300 schools have been closed by the Kennett government in the name of economic rationalism. We have seen thousands of teaching positions abolished in that state. We saw similar—but, I must admit, not to the same degree—action taken by the previous Liberal‐National Party government in New South Wales. Thousands of teaching positions were abolished and school maintenance programs were allowed to run down.

The New South Wales Labor government is one of the few state governments in this country that is improving in real terms the funding for government schools and is trying to clean up the mess that was created under previous ministers such as Metherell and Chadwick.

On top of all this, you have the enrolment benchmark adjustment savings device to cover students who leave the government school sector and move to private schools or non-government schools. That is intended to be the outcome of this legislation. Let us make no bones about it. This is not about choice because choice already exists. This is about the active promotion of students to leave government schools and move to non-government schools.

The level of funding available to states is going to be reduced for each student in such circumstances by $1,700. That $1,700 represents the level of recurrent funding from the federal government that is provided to state governments for students in a government school. I believe this legislation will cause serious damage to the government school system in this country in the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens strongly oppose this legislation for the reasons given my colleague Senator Margetts from the Greens (WA) and reasons given by many other speakers, including Senator Forshaw, who just preceded me. We stand very strongly for an enhanced public education system in this country. We stand very strongly for equal access to an excellent education system for all Australians, because fundamental to a fair go in an egalitarian society is the access to all levels of education by the citizens of that society. We are talking in particular about children who are being schooled to not only gain work when they leave the schooling system but also find fulfilment in life. If the education system fails them there, their prospects are blighted for the rest of their lives.

PARA.BREAK: Australia has a remarkably good education system, for all its faults and for all the criticism we might aim at it. We only have to measure it up against education systems elsewhere to see that. I will not canvass the litany of faults with this legislation but sum marise it in sheer economic terms. What the government is doing is cutting funding to public education.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at spending in Australia on education, you will find that we are at the bottom rung amongst OECD nations. That will come as a shock to many Australians who believe that we are amongst the top spenders. Wrong; we are amongst the bottom spenders in OECD nations. We are down with Portugal and other countries at the bottom level.

In the run‐up to the last election, we Greens made a commitment to people concerned about education that we would fight during this period of parliament to increase spending over the triennium by a billion dollars to at least bring us into the mid range of spending on education per capita with other OECD nations. Here we have legislation going in exactly the opposite direction. It is pulling money out of the public education system.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's not.

—Of course the minister is going to say, `No, it's not.' Of course she is going to argue that it is doing wonders for education. The reality is that this bill is part of the government's economic fundamentalist policy which says, `Put it across to the private sector.' The minister can roll her eyes, but that is what this legislation is about.
—Choice to parents.

—Absolutely. Give choice to the stock exchange, give choice to parents, but take choice from other children while you are doing it. Give choice to those who are most advantaged and have the best wherewithal, but take it away from those who are least advantaged and have the least wherewithal. That is what it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The cut will be of the order of $158 million a year on top of the cut already in untied grants to the states, which means education in the public sector will be cut by somewhere between $250 and $400 million a year. So we are moving towards half a billion dollars per annum being cut from education, when the Greens are saying that we should be going in exactly the opposite direction by exactly the opposite amount.

BREAK.PARA: What is it that determines whether a parent sends her or his child to a public or a private school? The single biggest factor is pupil-teacher ratio. The single biggest disadvantage to the public sector from this cut in funding is that, because they do not have the money, they cannot match the ability of private schools, particularly smaller private schools, to have a better teacher-pupil ratio. Never mind the fact that the government loses its ability to ensure that schools are presenting an equal education opportunity in the private sector to the public sector.

The fact is that the public sector is having the rug pulled from under it by this legislation. Every time the parents of a student choose to take their child out of the public sector and put them into a private school, the government will cut $1,000 to $2,000 out of the public school system. It will transfer some of that money across to the private school system.

So you have a treadmill or a self-enhancing system which is going to inexorably, over coming years, favour the private sector at the disadvantage of the public sector. There are figures bandied about—we have heard them in this debate—as to how many tens of thousands of students are going to leave the public sector and go across to the private sector in the next few years. What we do know is that process is being enhanced by this government legislation to the detriment of one of the fundamental institutions of a liberal democratic society, which is an excellent public school system.

The Greens stand against this legislation. We will vote against this legislation—notwithstanding the fact that there has been some very heartfelt lobbying. In particular, I can draw attention to the Steiner schools which favour this legislation. It will enable them to be able to get up and running in smaller communities around Australia where, arguably, they are in the private sector producing excellence in education.

The overall impact will be to the detriment of the public school system—the fair go system; the system upon which we rely in ensuring that every child has access to good education in this country. That is why the Greens are opposed to the legislation. That is why the Greens will be supporting amendments from the Labor Party which do the best they can to remove some of the worst aspects of this legislation and its impact against the interest of an excellent public school system in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak only briefly. The Democrats passionately oppose the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996. Other speakers have clearly articulated in this debate what so many of us identify as an incredible funding fiddle. So when the minister says, `No, it's not at the expense of public schools,' she is wrong, and other speakers have clearly demonstrated why she is wrong. It is a massive funding fiddle.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason I want to speak is that I want to talk about this rhetoric of choice. It seems that in Australia at the moment it does not matter what policy decision you want to make. As long as you wrap it up and attach the word `choice' to it, it is okay. But it is not okay. When you look at the policy implications and the long-term implications of what this government is calling choice, it is not okay for public education.

I would say that all of us in the Senate have economic choice. We can decide whether we want to send our children to private non-government schools or to government schools. We are fortunate. We have economic choice, but a huge number of Australians do not have that choice. It is the role of government to make sure that those who do not have economic choice do not get inferior choice of education. It is the role of government to say that, for the majority of students in this country who still choose—and in many cases do not have any choice—to attend public schools, they will not be disadvantaged by policy decisions which are aimed at luring or certainly making it easier for people to move from the public school system and all that that entails.

That is what choice does not address: who pays for the choice? Who pays for this choice? Those who already have economic choice are the parents and the students and the teachers who are part of the public education system. If this bill were to fail, the future of non-government schools is not in jeopardy. There are some excellent non-government schools that have great teachers. The kids who go there have wonderful opportunities for learning. They have access to resources and sporting facilities and all of the things that make education a pleasure. But who pays in the long run? Under this bill, kids who do not have choice, kids who do not have access to those resources, will pay in the long run.

You can talk all you like about how this is not taking money away from public schools. It is. If you want to talk about choice, in taking money from the public system and moving it across in anticipation of a shift from public education, the life choices of children who attend public education are affected. They are affected because state governments do not have the same resources to provide computers, for example. They are a luxury in a lot of state schools. Teacher numbers are affected. We all know the rules which say you can have X number of teachers if you have X number of students. We all know about the quality of teaching that goes on when you have small classes. Course options are affected. Children who go to these state schools will not have the same opportunity to study the same number of subjects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially in the country.

—Yes, especially in country schools. Teacher morale is affected because we are saying, `Oh, yes it's the role of government to provide public education, but we don't actually think it is quite as important as we used to think it is.' We are not, by legislation, reinforcing the importance of the public school system.

SPEECH.PARA: I keep saying, for those who do not have choice, that it is not about choice. It is transferring options. It is saying to people in public schools, `Sorry, you're stuck here and you have to take the quality that you get here.' This government is saying, `We're going to help the others set up. There is nothing wrong with that because we want to give them choice.' I say to this government: have your choice. People who have economic choice have economic choice, but do not make the students, the parents and the teachers of the public system pay for your notion of choice.

We hear a lot about those who are going to have the skills of the future. Robert Reich writes about this extensively. He talks about the one-fifth who have the skills and the four-fifths who do not. I will tell you who will end up in the four-fifths under this government's policies: it will be all the children who go to public schools. They will not have the opportunity to access the resources to equip them with the kinds of skills that are going to be necessary in the so-called new world order and globalisation and all the things that are going to affect life opportunities for students next century. I think it is disgraceful that this government is looking at making this move.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in this debate on matters of public interest to speak about the ABC and, in particular, about Radio Australia. The ABC is one of Australia's primary institutions with a very significant and valued role in Australian life. The government therefore wants the ABC to continue doing what it does best and will ensure that it remains an independent national broadcaster delivering quality programming to audiences as efficiently as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC will receive around $530 million in 1996-97 and $500 million in 1997-98. This funding represents a very strong commitment in a time where financial restraint is necessary. We promised on 2 March to improve the Australian economy and the situation of Australia for all Australians, and that is what we will be doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You promised to maintain funding for the ABC.

—Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator Bolkus goes on over there saying `Look what you're doing.' Senator Bolkus, had Labor, when it was in government, actually done something about the Australian economy and actually done something about retiring debt when it sold Qantas, when it sold off the Commonwealth Bank and when it spent beyond its means, we would not be in the situation we are in today. Given the fact that Labor spent beyond its means, we are in a situation where there do have to be cuts. We regret those cuts, but we are a responsible government and we are not into spending beyond our means and spending the money of the next generation.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the issue of the ABC needs to be addressed and given that its funding will be reduced, the government recognised that the ABC would need guidance to address the community's highest priorities of its activities. We have established a review under Mr Mansfield to redefine and reposition the future direction of the ABC. The terms of reference of the review stress factors such as the importance of independence and high quality service and the importance of services to rural and remote communities and other significant groups not well served by other broadcasting services.

The outcome of the review will be reported to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, before the end of next year. In making its report, the review will be seeking the views of the ABC's audiences, the public broadcasters themselves and other interested parties. The minister has given his assurance that the ABC will remain an independent broadcaster and that its role is to deliver quality programming to audiences as efficiently as possible.

As I said, tough decisions have to be made with regard to government spending because of the parlous state in which the former Labor government left this economy. I only have to remind the Senate that the previous government announced a headline surplus of $720 million when it brought down the 1995-96 budget. In December 1995, that was downgraded to a surplus of $115 million. So, from the budget through to December last year, we went from $720 million in surplus to $115 million in surplus. By the time 12 March came after the election, when the information was given to Mr Costello and Mr Howard and they revealed it to the public, we suddenly found that this magnificent surplus of $720 million had gone to a deficit of $280 million. We were looking at a hole in that year's budget.

In addition, every time we are concerned about spending cuts, we ought to be reminded that Australians pay $10 billion per annum in interest on public debt—debt racked up mostly by 13 years of Labor when they were profligate and they spent beyond their means. What we now have is an interest bill of $10 billion, and every Australian ought to remember that. Every Australian ought to remember, too, what happened when the Commonwealth Bank was sold—mind you, there were promises that they were not going to sell the second half before the election and then they did—and when Qantas was sold. Was any of that money used to retire debt? No. That money was not used to retire debt. You kept on your spending spree—spending money of the next generation.

Many of the cuts that the coalition has had to make have not been easy and there has been every attempt to ensure that they were spread as fairly as possible across the portfolios. The Australian people voted for a change on 2 March. What they wanted was a responsible government that just would not keep spending willy‐nilly. They gave us the job to overcome the problems that occurred due to the irresponsibility of the previous Labor government and the task of getting Australia back on track.

The ABC has not been quarantined from the need to reduce government spending. Some of the hard decisions that have had to be made in the ABC are not as a result of the cuts, but as a result of a $13.5 million blow-out in the 1996-97 ABC budget itself, hanging over from the previous government. So some of the cuts that have been made are in fact as a result of a blow-out in the ABC budget.

Taking into account all the constraints which will be necessary and an understanding that since Radio Australia was launched in 1939 the world has changed, technology has changed and that there are new players in the field such as Australia Television, the Internet and so on, I would like to remind the Senate of the role Radio Australia has played.

Radio Australia, as I just mentioned, was launched in 1939 and has been broadcasting to the world for more than 50 years. It operates from the Southbank Centre in Melbourne. It produces 43 hours of programs for air each day in English and eight regional languages. It is distributed principally on short‐wave radio but also by audio transcription for relay on local regional stations and, increasingly, by satellite, cable and via the Internet.

Radio Australia produces a comprehensive tailored service of news, information and cultural programs about Australia, its people and policies to the Asia-Pacific region in particular but also beyond. It is also involved in foreign language program production, which specialises in the major languages of the Asia-Pacific region.

International broadcasting, particularly radio, is an effective way of reaching a large and diverse audience and having an impact on the regional information agenda. It is cost effective—it is cheaper than television—it is faster than newspapers and is accessible by resource-poor audiences. We ought to remember that many people who cannot afford a television may have access to a radio. Some of those people may be potential students for Australia. That is a factor that ought to be kept in mind.

One of the other roles that Radio Australia can play, especially with its English broadcasting programs, is in education, by assisting people to learn, to speak and to understand English. I know for a fact that there are people in the Asia-Pacific region who use English-speaking programs for that purpose and value it.

Radio Australia also benefits travellers and residents abroad. Any Australian who has been out of the country for a significant period of time would know this. I can well remember that when I spent six months in Pennsylvania—on the smell of an oily rag, as a young academic trying to develop my skills—one of my great joys was to sit with my little, portable Grundig short‐wave radio and tune into Radio Australia. Sometimes I got the AFL football; other times I got the news.

It was of great comfort to me, because it was a fairly lonely experience being away for that period of time with not much money to spend on other activities. It was a great source of comfort and information to me and enabled me to keep up to date. I know there are many others who spend longer periods away from Australia who value being able to keep in touch with developments and changes at home.

Public diplomacy in the Asia-Pacific region is also an aspect which is assisted by the programs emanating out of Radio Australia. It also demonstrates Australia's commitment to Asia and projects into Asia an image of Australia. It can be used to promote Australian technology, tourism, trade and culture and to contribute to international forums and training programs in Asia and the Pacific.

It also complements Australian foreign aid and trade policy objectives. Work has been done with government departments to produce materials furthering the understanding of Australia. This understanding and relationship is very important to maintain and help with business and trade.

It must be remembered that trade with Asian and Pacific countries is vital. That has been brought home to us just in the last week with the APEC conference. The APEC region is Australia's most important and fastest growing regional market. The region now accounts for 73 per cent of Australia's total merchandise trade. Over the past decade, Australia's merchandise trade with APEC has increased at an annual trend of 9.7 per cent, while merchandise trade with the rest of the world has grown significantly slower, at 8.3 per cent.

The support for Radio Australia can be assessed by audience numbers. I have been advised that the regular short-wave audience listening at least once a week is estimated to be around five million. The total reach of people who tune into Radio Australia at least once a year is estimated to be 20,000,000.

BREAK.PARA: Radio Australia broadcasts in nine languages. The organisation receives a considerable amount of mail from people in those nine languages, giving examples of how it has benefited them. It has been found in surveys that Radio Australia is one of the preferred services used by the elite of the region, including those who have a higher education and higher income. It is also known to be an important source of regional information for leaders and is monitored by government agencies for internal distribution.

I refer to some examples of people who have written to Radio Australia expressing support. One is Norodom Sihanouk, the King of Cambodia. I do not have time to read it, but there is a quote from an honorary minister assisting the King of Cambodia saying that when they were spending some time in Korea they were able to monitor what was happening through Radio Australia.

Other examples are King Norodom Ranariddh, the first Prime Minister of Cambodia; the minister for the environment in Cambodia, Dr Mo Mareth; Mahendra Chaudry, Secretary-General of the Fijian Labour Party; and Bernard Dowiyogo, the President of the Republic of Nauru. They have all written saying that they use Radio Australia as a source of information.
