The chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan—whom many of us did not know much about until a little while ago; we are now more familiar with him—listens to Radio Australia to get a round-up of world news before he goes to sleep. He said that it was the only reliable world news at that time of the morning. A number of other Australian trade commissioners and consuls throughout the Asia-Pacific region and beyond have written saying that they support Radio Australia and the work that it does to keep them in touch.

I was interested to find out that Indonesia has a Radio Australia listeners club, for the Indonesian service, which has a branch in every city in Indonesia. One would wonder whether they would have bothered establishing a club if they were not so loyal. I am told that you can go into a city in Indonesia and meet with Radio Australia listeners who have formed a club.

Radio Australia is a fairly minor player compared with other international broadcasters, such as Voice of America and the BBC. If there is a decision to cut back on Radio Australia, the result will be lost audiences, and it could be hard to get them back. If we leave the broadcasting to other places, then we could be disadvantaged by other countries setting the regional information agenda, such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan and France. It must be remembered that these are our economic and political competitors.

I must emphasise that, if Radio Australia's services are reduced, the blame should be sheeted fairly and squarely home to the former Labor government. That is where the blame will lie. If those services I have just mentioned have to be cut back, it will be because Labor left this country and the economy in such an appalling state that decisions have to be made. I hope that, as the review takes place, we attempt to make—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bitter on the back bench.

—You are much better in opposition and on the other side. The way you carry on, you will be there for a very long time. We all have to accept that there will be changes. We all recognise the effect of new technologies. We all recognise that there are some changes that need to be made to the services offered by the ABC, including regional, rural and overseas services. If this results in a cut in those services it will be because the previous Labor government left us with a situation where we have to cut some services. The blame lies at the door of the former Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to focus my comments on this government's industry policy and budget measures. This government lacks any vision when it comes to Australian industry. Innovation is as much lacking in this government's industry policy as innovation will be lacking in industry itself over the next decade. This government's changes to industry research and development will stifle the progress that Australian industry has achieved over the past decade. This government's axing of the computer bounty will directly cost jobs. Combine these two changes with the funding cuts to Austrade and AusIndustry and this government's policies will be truly devastating not only for Australian industry generally but also for industry development specifically.

SPEECH.PARA: The business people I speak to are a little perplexed about this government. Australian business thought that the election of the conservatives would provide them with an environment of growth. They must be wondering where their votes have gone. It is interesting to see that the only major portfolio announcements for industry this year have been negative. Business people are shocked.

If there was one good news story over the past decade for industry to sell which needs to be highlighted—and indeed there are many good news stories because of Labor's role in industry development—then it would have to be the dramatic rise in commercial investment in research and development. Business spending on R&D tripled between 1981‐82 and 1993-94 from 0.23 per cent of GDP to 0.7 per cent of GDP.

What is particularly impressive is the rate of research and development intensity—the ratio of research and development to value adding—which in manufacturing has tripled, rising over the decade to 1993 from one per cent to three per cent. This growth was achieved through government intervention that encouraged and rewarded industry investment in innovation, cutting edge technology and research.

The reason government intervention was needed was that in the early 1980s industry was trailing the world significantly in research investment. Australians were destined to have a lower standard of living if the economy could not shift from an economy of assets to an economy of knowledge.

Labor recognised this and took a variety of actions over the past 10 years that resulted in the remarkable figures that I have just quoted. Commentators predicted that if this growth in innovation was maintained throughout the next decade then our economy would be transformed. Professor Peter Sheehan from the Centre for Strategic Economic Studies at the University of Victoria predicted that if investment continued to grow as it had over the past 10 years, levels of R&D spending would be high by world standards and many industry and service sectors would be leading edge and exports of sophisticated goods and services would be a major force in the national economy. Surely that is a desirable objective. It is not for this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you, Senator Mackay. It is not for this government. The penny‐pinchers have won over the innovators and they have won over the people with vision. The budget is proof of the product of that battle. The Business Review Weekly headline last week—`Goodbye Clever Country'—is right. One of the most successful industry policies has been scuttled by the Costello juggernaut of fiscal contraction. The result will be innovation contraction.

SPEECH.PARA: The foundation of this policy of innovation was a successful 150 per cent tax concession on research and development expenditure—a business welfare initiative that even the bastion of economic rationalism the Industry Commission described last year as having brought net benefits to the Australian economy. The commission argued that its removal would lead to a reduction in GDP and that the scheme should not be changed. For once the Industry Commission got it right.

The reduction from 150 per cent to 125 per cent is a sign of this government's lack of understanding of industry. Industry has said that the reduction results in an actual halving of the concession because its value is in the percentage over the 100 per cent that would be available if the expenditure was written off as a normal expense. Companies are already considering moving their research units offshore.

Labor was not the only party to recognise the importance of research and development incentives. We were not the only country to recognise its importance. Our closest neighbours, Singapore and Malaysia, offer 200 per cent concessions. Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu surveyed 125 companies, and 57 per cent that claim the concession said the reduction would have a negative effect on their research and development decisions. Nearly a quarter of the respondents, and 34 per cent of those already claiming the concession, said that they were already considering moving their research and development overseas.

Taking the reduction in tax concession and the abolition of the syndication scheme together, that amounts to $2.2 billion being ripped out of industry research and development over the next four years. The government is taking a gamble with our investment into the future. Is it even worth saying that yet again the retention of both of these schemes was a pre-election promise of this government? It is a repetitive theme of debate in this chamber. I suppose the government thinks: if one promise is broken why not break them all? It is obvious that innovation and industry development does not fall into the bag of the core promise. If one promise is broken, then we see the rest fall—and we have seen them continually fall. I think this government is counting on the fact that the public will become immune to continual bad news.

I will continue my examination of the government's attack on the industry through its budget measures; namely, its abolition of the computer bounty. Bipartisan support for the bounty has seen the program set to continue until the year 2000. Again this is another forgotten promise and again another promise broken. How can industry effectively plan for the future when the government changes its mind as often as this government seems to?

The computer bounty, along with other programs that the government has axed, was aimed at encouraging the development of Australia's information technologies. The exports of Australian computer hardware has increased. Information technology will be the major industry of the future, and Australia could have been riding the crest of the wave. Revenue to Australia from information technology grew from less than $20 billion in 1990 to over $33 billion in 1995. The facts say it all.

This is also an industry centred on small enterprises. I add very proudly that the ACT is home to a vibrant information technology industry dominated by small operators. Nationally, 95 per cent of these businesses employ fewer than 20 people. So we are talking about not only small business but micro‐businesses—very dynamic and happening organisations that have risked a lot to take Australia to the forefront of that technological wave.

Already companies have stated publicly that contracts have been cancelled because of the decision of this government to return to the bottom line budget cuts. Contracts cancelled mean jobs lost—not a favourable outcome when the unemployment figures are so appalling.

In light of these changes, it is little wonder that the government follows up with budgetary cuts to AusIndustry and Austrade. In all reality, will there be much demand on these two bodies with the changes to the bounty and research and development? I doubt it, because not too many people will be able to afford to invest.

AusIndustry, a relatively newly expanded body, has had its funding slashed by $34 million while Austrade, Australia's trade commission, has been cut by $100 million. Australian businesses need the support that these two bodies give, the push to establish and the push to export. They have been a successful part of Australian industry. Austrade does take Australian business to the world. This government is assuming that industry can do it on its own. Maybe some will—I am sure many of them will—but how many will fail in the process from a lack of that key support provided by that government body? I repeat: what a gamble this government is taking with Australia's investment.

Australian industry was moving towards being a major exporter of leading edge technology and products, but now I foresee that Australian industry will be a major exporter of jobs, particularly regional jobs. Although the past decade has seen dramatic improvements in industry investment in research and development, we will still trail behind countries like Sweden, Japan, the US, Finland and France in research and development spending.

PARA.BREAK: We have got a long way to go. Before this government came in we had a hope of reach ing those goals. Another decade of similar growth would have seen Australia as a leader in research rather than as a follower—a leader in the provision of sophisticated technology rather than just a consumer—and our economy and our children would have reaped the benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Bureau of Industry Economics, the small business sector contributed almost $500 million to Australian research and development in 1993-94. Research and development spending by small business has had a faster average annual growth rate than expenditure by big business. Indeed, the sector expenditure on research and development trebled in the decade from 1984.

This is not surprising, since government intervention encouraged investment at that time. It meant that once high‐risk ventures would be rewarded in some way, if not in product development. It is not a surprise that the President of the United States, Bill Clinton, chose Australia to raise the importance of information technology in the future. Information technology will be a vehicle of social and economic enfranchisement for many people around the world. But will Australia be a part of this revolution?

The high‐risk gamble here is the one that this government is taking with Australian industry research and development. The result will be many years off. This gamble will not pay off. This government's policy for industry will be seen as a mistake. In 10 years time we will be looking back and seeing a flawed policy and wondering where we could have got to if the path that Labor initiated was continued with. My greatest fear is that it will take a long time for this government to realise the seriousness of its mistake and it will not move quickly enough to rectify what I see as a glaring and appalling deficiency in its policy structure.

Australian industry will suffer. There will be fewer jobs. We will lose the momentum of riding the crest of the wave of the latest phase in the information technology revolution. The future will be that much less bright for the next generation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to place on the record my response to Senator Abetz's highly distorted and misleading representation of comments made by me during the second reading debate yesterday on the schools bill. I was very careful to say that the Democrats could have lived with the abolition of the new schools policy provided it did not proceed at the expense of the public school sector. We do not have a problem with new non-government schools starting up; we have a problem, firstly, with allowing those schools to start up in a completely unplanned, ad hoc and unrestricted manner and, secondly, with funding those schools by taking money from the public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very clear that, without any restrictions, a number of the new schools which seek to start operation will be small. They will be much smaller than those state schools in Victoria, for example, which are being forced to close down. It is quite clear that a number of them will come from fundamentalist religious backgrounds.

I simply asked the Senate to consider whether it was good policy to fund those sorts of schools and that size of school at the expense of mainstream public education in this country. I believe the answer to that question should be no. If Senator Abetz supports that proposition, then he is seriously out of touch with the vast majority of Australians. He is certainly seriously out of touch with Australian parents who have children in both government and non-government schools.

I also want to address Senator Tierney's remarks about the re‐emergence of the divisive state aid debate. One thing which was very clear at the two days of hearings of the education committee—and is also very clear to me when I talk to parents and educators around the country—is that very few people know about this bill and its impact on public education. Senator Tierney is correct in saying that people are not marching in the streets, but I suggest that they will be. It will not perhaps be in the next few weeks. It may not even be in the next few months. But right now the letters are pouring into my office and they are coming from people who would have wanted to have appeared before that committee but did not do so because there simply was not time.
I take the opportunity today to put on the public record some of the remarks made by people out there. A letter from the Queanbeyan East Public School says:
Despite your coalition's promises about a `fair go' for lower and middle income Australians, this legislation attacks one of the basic tenets of our society—the right to a decent education.

If this Bill is passed, then Australia's expenditure on education will be greatly eroded. This Bill will entrench two levels of Government schools in Australia—elite and second class. Only when a country's expenditure on education moves away from patronage for the elite does that country's ability to control their future approach reality. We would like to know the numbers of the Liberal and National Party sitting members who attended private schools. Has the Government considered the impact on all Australian schools, particularly in rural areas? Could you please consider the damage this reduction in expenditure will cause to our community's value for education.
A letter from Rozelle from Ms Jeanette Holloway says:

The government is wrong in saying that there will be a greater choice by removing the restrictions that have been in place to assess the quality of a new school before it opens. The predicted increase in the number of subsidised non‐government schools will lead to the closure of public schools and so reduce the CHOICE that parents will have within their areas.
Specifically I call for:

1. The removal of the `Enrolment Adjustment Benchmark'. It is false to say that the government saves several thousand dollars every time a student transfers to a non‐government school and it will start a snowball effect of decreasing standards within the public school education system due to under‐funding.

2. The enshrinement in legislation of the provision that school education be planned, so that all can be involved in the decision making processes. The quality of education and training will affect the long‐term upgrading of industry. This should not be left to market forces.
3. The enshrinement in legislation of the principle of UNIVERSAL FREE PUBLIC SCHOOLING.
A letter from Leeton High School in New South Wales says:

BREAK.PARA: The Leeton High School Council would like to register its opposition to the proposed changes to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Assistance) Bill 1996.

We believe that it is the right for all individuals to receive a quality education. Reduction to funding to Government Schools, for whatever purpose, can only be detrimental to the equality of opportunity for all. The proposed change to the legislation has the potential to create a two class system whereby Government Schools will become second rate institutions. We urge you to reconsider the proposals that will see a reduction in the per capita grant to Government Schools under the Recurrent Grants Program.
Our community will not blindly accept such a loss to its school.
A short excerpt from a quite long and well argued letter from the Sydney Road Community School says:

Firstly, we are concerned at what we see as the lack of timely consultation regarding the government's intentions with this bill. As a school community, we pride ourselves on the democratic participation that is a priority in decision making in school. It is a great shock—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Senate long today. I notice there are other senators who wish to make a contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: My contribution is merely to raise a matter which is currently doing the rounds in Canberra. That is a suggestion which has been forthcoming from some people in the Department of the Environment that we should put a charge on recreational boat owners who enter the waters of the Great Barrier Reef.If you happen to live in Canberra, I am sure this might well be a wonderful idea.

Unfortunately for the thousands and thousands of people who make their home on the coast of Queensland—and most of the coast of Queensland is adjacent to the waters of the Great Barrier Reef—such a proposal is absolutely ludicrous because it would basically be a charge on people who want to use what is effectively their own backyard. There is quite a degree of difference between people who use national parks or world heritage areas for a commercial purpose and private individuals who wish to utilise those facilities for their own personal recreation.

Heaven help us in this country if we ever go down the route that has been suggested by various government departments from time to time where we would put charges on Australians enjoying recreational opportunities. There was a suggestion put forward by the Industry Commission some years ago that we put a charge on people going to the beach. That suggestion received the short shrift it deserved because it was ludicrous and contrary to the Australian way of life.

BREAK.PARA: As a Queenslander and as a representative of the National Party, let me say very clearly: nobody would accept a proposal to put a charge on private individuals using Lake Burley Griffin; nobody would accept a proposal for private individuals to be charged for taking their own pleasure craft on Sydney Harbour or on Moreton Bay; so why should people in Canberra or people in the department think that it would be at all acceptable that a charge could be put on private individuals who use their own boat on the waters of Queensland that happen to be adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef? It is thoroughly ludicrous.

Let me make it very clear that my National Party parliamentary colleagues and I will not accept any proposal that the department may come forward with to that end. I know Senator Hill is a very reasonable and intelligent man and I know Senator Hill would see through a suggestion like that coming from the department. But we can save the bureaucrats a lot of time by saying that the way of life that people enjoy in Queensland, especially along the Queensland coast, must be preserved. The right of people to get their own boat and use the waters of the Queensland coast is one of those rights that must be preserved; it is part of the way we live.

People already pay registration charges to the state government and that is a completely different issue because every boat owner has to pay those charges—and they help fund the operation of harbours and marine matters. It is not at all acceptable to think that we would be willing to wear this. It is very fanciful, indeed, for the bureaucrats to think that they might ever get support from the parliamentary National Party for that proposal. I say in conclusion that those people who might be sharpening their pencils in departmental offices here in Canberra can put them away, and put away the bit of paper as well, because this proposal is one that should go for a long swim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to report the very responsible decision by the government, announced by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, to invest $2 billion in reforming Australia's rail system. This is a visionary policy and will overcome the mess left by the former Labor government. We have a situation in Australia where the rail system has been allowed to run down disgracefully. Yet we have the sorts of economies available that would make rail transport very competitive with road transport if it was set up and run properly. That is what the minister has announced he intends to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The government will offer Australian National Rail for sale. It will sell the Commonwealth interest in the National Rail Corporation and set up a national track authority to manage the system which will run both public and private trains. This decision is a renaissance for rail in Australia. It will reverse the slide over the last 13 years in rail's share of the national transport system.

The decision is essential because if we let it run on as the previous Labor government had let it run on, the financial and job consequences were going to be absolutely catastrophic. Labor's mismanagement was condemning Australian National Rail to a slow and certain death. The former Minister for Land Transport, the member for Charlton, Bob Brown, stands condemned for his role in this. What he did was set up National Rail, which was basically a freight operation. That was fine, but he left the Australian national railways, the remaining segment, to hang out to dry. He took away its most lucrative business and left it with all its debts.

You do not have to be a mathematical whiz to work out that if you create a situation like that and just leave it year after year, with revenue plummeting and debt servicing rising, you have a financial catastrophe on your hands. That is what the last Labor government has left us with and that is what Minister Sharp has now moved decisively to fix up.

The extent of the mess left by the previous government is indicated by the fact that the taxpayer is currently subsidising each rail worker to the tune of $60,000. Within four years that is going to blow out, if this matter is left unattended, to $220,000 per worker. That was the subsidy this former government left us with. It has left us with a huge clean‐ up bill and the clean‐up bill has a $2 billion price tag attached to it.

Let me outline the essential elements of this policy. Rail services in Australia will be rejuvenated through private sector involvement. This government will take over the debt and it will leave the new owners with a clean state of unencumbered assets. A regime for competitive national track access will be established and there will be one authority, under the control of the government, which will manage and control the interstate network.

World's best practice has shown what can be achieved in rail with private sector involvement. I would just like to mention two examples. In the United States, rail has been traditionally privately owned. Their rail is up to four times more efficient than our rail system. New Zealand are recent newcomers to privatisation—so they are quite a good model to follow. Tranz Rail New Zealand was privatised in 1993. It is already 50 per cent more efficient than Australian National. It is carrying 15 per cent more freight than it was two years ago. So while our system has continued to decline under public ownership, in New Zealand under private ownership it is increasing.

Prior to this announcement by Minister Sharp there had been, with his approval, a number of pilot operations on the rail system where private companies were able to move freight. TNT is now offering a private freight service between Melbourne and Perth, and this package of reforms will allow this type of rail service to grow. Why so much is carried by road in this country, which has such an extensive rail network, has often amazed me. The reason why it has been is that, with a very inefficient public infrastructure, the carriers who depend on speed of delivery and timing could not trust the publicly owned utility to move the goods at the time they wanted them to.

If we give carriers control at both ends of an operation involving the moving of material from, say, Melbourne to Perth, as TNT is doing, they can move their prime movers into the rail depot in Melbourne, put the containers on a train and get their trucks to take them off at the other end. They control the operation from start to finish. With that sort of confidence and control, the private operators will access this service, and with that private sector involvement we will find, as we have found overseas, particularly in New Zealand, growth in rail traffic. This private sector involvement will also ensure that there are more jobs in rail than there are under this current system.

Freight will not be the only area of growth. This government is dedicated to turning two of our greatest potential tourist assets into dollar earners for Australia. I refer in particular to the Ghan and the Indian Pacific—world‐class rail journeys which would become, if a little flair and investment were added, very profitable businesses. We are offering those assets for sale to a private company. If they are not taken over by a private company, the government has guaranteed that those world‐class rail journeys will continue under a public corporation. But we will be putting much more of a tourist spin on it, particularly in the lead-up to and the lead away from the Olympic Games.

Let us look at what this turnaround will mean for jobs by contrasting what we are about to do with what Labor had done during its rather sorry and disgraceful stewardship of the rail system. During the last 13 years of Labor, 7,000 jobs were lost in the rail system. Under Australian National's business plan signed off by Kim Beazley and Laurie Brereton in the dying days of the Keating government another 1,000 jobs were earmarked to be lost.

This major micro‐economic reform we are intending to make will turn rail into an efficient, competitive and reliable transport provider. There are, of course, offset costs to achieve the reforms that are needed as a result of Labor's incompetent management of the system. The major components of the $2 billion package that Minister Sharp has announced include $112 million for redundancies, unfunded provisions from employee super and other entitlements of $90 million, acquisition of debt costing $779 million, a regional assistance package of $20 million to mitigate the effects of restructuring and $126 million to be expended on outstanding contracts and liabilities.

This government has made a very difficult decision. The last government left the rail system in a complete mess. We could not allow it to continue, but turning it around needed a very bold initiative. I am quite confident that, with a very imaginative combination of private and public sector involvement, the train system in this country will be back on track.

I would like to mention another aspect that is very important to my own area in northern New South Wales, and it relates to the world-class train making facility at Goninans in Newcastle. As part of Minister Sharp's restructuring package for rail, he is honouring and guaranteeing the contracts that already exist for the production of locomotives at the Goninans plant in Newcastle. At the moment they have a contract to build 120 first-class locomotives at a cost of $420 million. That will continue. It is essential that that continue because not only do we need a world-class system but we need a world-class freight carrying facility.

The former managers of Australian National and National Rail told us that, when the National Rail Corporation was set up in 1992, as part of the agreement the rolling stock that was handed over to them by the states was generally older stock. At any one point 25 per cent of it was out of action, needing repair. That is an intolerable situation. People will not freight materials if we have those sorts of inefficiencies. This situation is to be corrected, and we guarantee that the plan to correct that will stay in place. There are to be 120 new locomotives for Australian National and $420 million is to be spent on these contracts, which are a great job booster for the Hunter Valley.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Minister Sharp will be at Goninans tomorrow for the launch of the new diesel locomotives. I confidently predict that, as a result of this new arrangement, firms like Goninans have a very bright future because not only will they have the contracts to complete those but there are real flow‐on opportunities in the South-East Asian market for the building of similar types of locos for the tiger economies of South-East Asia.

I congratulate the government and the minister on this excellent package. It will put our rail network back on track and ensure that another piece of the jigsaw in the micro-economic reform agenda is put in place.

ANSWER.PARA: What he does not say is that in November last year he did exactly the same himself. The answer to the question is that it does put the two together. That is what I said in the very first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Develop ment and relates to a further outcome from political paybacks by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development that have compromised aviation safety in Australia. Can the minister confirm that a PA31 aircraft participating in a search and rescue precision aerial delivery system, or PADS, training exercise off Jervis Bay on 10 November was involved in a serious incident that almost resulted in the loss of the aircraft? Can the minister also confirm that the PADS training program has been suspended as a result of this incident?

—I am not sure that I have specific information on that matter. It seems to require a degree of technical advice that I am not presently able to provide. To the extent that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development is able to provide additional information, I will certainly ensure that that is brought before the Senate.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. While you are doing that, could you also ask the minister to provide to the Senate as a matter of urgency the incident report relating to this incident that was made to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, the SAR training occurrence report and the video taken of the training exercise?
—I will take all that on board.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer to the Hinchinbrook World Heritage area and the destructive resort proposed for it. Is it true that Keith Williams has threatened to begin dredging in the Hinchinbrook Channel next Monday, despite the deed of agreement requiring that baseline studies would be completed first? Is it true that Mr Williams, as we sit here, is dumping sand on the foreshore at Oyster Point, although you have maintained steadfastly that no artificial beach was to be built? Is it true that the dumping of sand there is threatening beach stone-curlews, which are listed as endangered? Finally, is it true that Mr Williams is dumping rock rubble 100 metres west along the creek at Oyster Point and for 25 metres, so far, into the channel to build a breakwater, for which you have given no permission, into the World Heritage area? Is that not against your deed of agreement and the World Heritage convention? If so, why have you not taken action on any of these matters? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Brown is referring to a press release that was put out today by the North Queensland Conservation Council, which made the allegations that he has repeated in here this afternoon. The position is that I have previously instructed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to advise me immediately there is any action taken by Mr Williams which is in breach of his legal obligations. I have said to the Senate that if there was any such action, I would respond to it equally quickly. I have received no advice of any breach of the agreement. The assertions by the North Queensland Conservation Council have been somewhat exaggerated in the past, and I wonder whether it might be the case again.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite my general instruction to GBRMPA, upon receiving this press release shortly before Senate question time, I specifically referred back to GBRMPA the allegations that were contained therein and asked for their urgent advice upon that. Not surprisingly, as I only got it just before question time, I have not got a response to that. In relation to the beach stone‐curlew, it is not listed as endangered under the Commonwealth legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question to that, Madam President. I ask the minister: if the allegations are true, will he cease the construction works on Keith Williams's enterprise to draw him into line and reconsider the whole enterprise if such a breach of the deed of agreement is occurring? Secondly, who is the person who is monitoring the building on‐site and is that monitoring continuing or is it a time to time event? I ask the minister: will he ensure that if the baseline studies are not done, dredging will not proceed until those baseline monitoring studies by an independent monitor are completed?
—Mr Williams must comply with his legal obligations, both under Queens land law and in accordance with the deed that we have entered into. If he fails to do so, we will take action to enforce it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I note that Mr Sharp has joyfully acknowledged the fact that Mr Max Moore-Wilton was, in a previous job, responsible for negotiating National Rail matters on behalf of the New South Wales government. Is Mr Moore-Wilton subject to confidentiality requirements with regard to his previous job or is he in a position to use information gained from that job to now assist the Commonwealth government in these matters? Is he also bound not to disclose information derived from his job at the Victorian Public Transport Corporation? What steps will the minister be taking to exclude Mr Moore-Wilton from any role in negotiations on matters relating to National Rail?

—That is a classic example of jumping to conclusions. You start off by asking whether there was any confidentiality agreement. Presumably, that is a matter that would be known to both Mr Moore-Wilton and the New South Wales government. It would not necessarily be known to the federal government, but it probably is. You then go on and ask whether he will be excluded from any negotiations, presumably because you have reached the conclusion that he is in breach of some confidentiality arrangement.
—I am asking whether there is a conflict of interest.
—You are asking me whether he will, without having ascertained the facts of whether he is in breach of any confidentiality agreement.
—What's the answer?

—I don't know; I will find out for you. If you are seriously expecting me to get up here and tell you the details of a confidentiality agreement between a senior public servant and the New South Wales government, you are expecting a lot more than most other people would expect.

BREAK.PARA: The point I make to you once again is that before you jump to conclusions, you ought to await the proper answer. After all, I presume you would say that if there is a breach of the agreement, someone should not be able to use that information in confidential discussions and negotiations. If, on the other hand, there was no confidentiality agreement, presumably, it follows that you are able to continue to be involved in those discussions. Why ask me to give you a commitment that he will be excluded from the negotiations before you even have an answer to your first question? I will get back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I thank Senator Alston for that answer. Perhaps he can get back to me on this matter. Given that the Victorian government will be considering its attitude to the sale of the Commonwealth interest in National Rail and the fact that Mr Max Moore-Wilton is chairman of the Victorian Public Transport Corporation and Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, does a conflict of interest situation arise and which one or two of his three current employers' interests will he be serving?

—Clearly, this is not a supplementary question. If you are asking whether his current combination of positions constitutes a conflict of interest, the answer to that involves a judgment that is totally unrelated to whether he signed any confidentiality agreement with the New South Wales government. It is not a supplementary question.
—It is all about Max Moore-Wilton.

—You agree with that, Senator Collins; I am very pleased to know that. Perhaps you might like to give some pre-match instructions to the temporary leader and make sure that he gets it right in future. If you want an answer to a completely unrelated so-called supplementary question, I will get back to you.
—There is a conflict of interest.

—I know you maintain there is. It does not follow that we concede that for one moment. Judgments about whether there are any conflicts of interest are clearly matters that the government has to address.
—Who is he representing—Victoria or the Commonwealth?

—I would be very surprised if this has not been trawled over exhaustively both inside government and in the entrails of your caucus room. The answer I am sure will be one that will not make you particularly satisfied, but I will get back to you. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. The quarterly `Social Security compliance report', which was tabled this morning, reported that your department had significantly improved its efforts on the fraud and compliance front in the September quarter of 1996. What improvements in administration has this government put in place to bring about these dramatic savings of taxpayers' money and how do these reforms assist genuine welfare recipients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good question from Senator Knowles. Do you remember, Madam President, the former minister Peter Baldwin who constantly used to crow how you could not do anything to the social security system to make it any cleaner? In August last year, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, what we do by way of compliance is now recognised as being of world leading standard in many respects.

We, when we were in opposition, did suggest that it could be done better. He would rubbish us and would crow again about how great his system was. I remember him talking about a United States professor in 1993 who said how top notch the system was and how it could not be improved.

These new compliance figures that were tabled this morning put the lie to all these claims. If Mr Baldwin's system was so good, how come the department in the past year has increased the number of compliance reviews by 27.6 per cent? That is over one-quarter more reviews, with the resulting increase in payment cancellations nearly 30 per cent. The figure that really exposes Mr Baldwin's posturing is that recovery of debts has increased by $26 million in the quarter to $84.4 million, which is an increase in debt recovery of 44 per cent.

Other improvements have been a 31 per cent increase in investigations of reports from the public and a 20 per cent rise in the savings achieved from data-matching. It is hard to claim that you have got a world-class social security system with no substantial rorting if, in the space of one year, the department has achieved 20 per cent plus gains across a range of fraud and compliance indicators. I welcome the improvements that the department has made since the change of government. I do commend the department's hardworking staff for their efforts which have been vital to the success of the exercise.

This government has placed greater priority on addressing fraud and non-compliance. We have announced a number of further initiatives in the budget, such as: tightening activity testing, changed penalty provisions, medical reviews, computer investigation and analysis, extra resources for raising recovery of debts, legislative changes to allow DSS to maximise overpayment recovery, and data-matching to include parenting allowance customers as well as customers' aliases and maiden names.

For too many years, the vast majority of honest DSS customers have been besmirched by the cheating of the few. We intend to restore the integrity of the social security system. This first quarterly report indicates that we are moving in the right direction. We are aiming to bring back respect rather than suspicion for social security recipients. We intend to eliminate the waste of taxpayers' money. The member for Werriwa, Mark Latham, said in a very interesting speech last July:

For those who support the ideals of the wealthy estate, the restoration of its relevance and legitimacy is a first order task in public policy. To be certain, a system of social provision which lacks the confidence of those who do the providing—that is, the taxpayers—is a system in need of reform.
Senator Mackay, Gary Gray, the national secretary, and Barry Jones, the national president in their recent post-mortem for the Labor Party on why they lost the election said:
It seemed that everyone knew of a welfare cheat. This aroused real antagonism for many traditional supporters who felt that some groups were receiving special treatment at their expense.

I would like to issue a challenge to the opposition parties: pass our budget measures and start to be relevant to mainstream Australia. These figures demonstrate that further action by government can save taxpayers' funds. Do you support cheats or taxpayers? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can I say to Senator Newman that maybe she should be relevant to this Senate by coming in here to handle her own bills in the future. Minister Vanstone, has your attention been drawn to comments by the chairman of National Legal Aid, Mr Chris Stanisforth, who stated that the Howard government was the first Australian government to turn its back on the notion of equality before the law as a consequence of its funding cuts to legal aid? Is it a fact that the government is proceeding down the American path of lawlessness, as Mr Stanisforth himself claimed, if it proceeds with its budget decision to slash some $40 million a year for each of the next three years from legal aid? Is it also a fact that, as a result of your funding cuts—cuts which breached the promise that you gave before the election—130,000 of the 435,000 people who use legal aid each year would lose access to legal aid services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. No, the comments of this gentleman have not been drawn to my attention. But there has been a range of comments on changed arrangements for legal aid funding. What the Commonwealth has said is that the states need to look after legal aid funding for state matters. There has been some consternation and some disagreement about it, but that is the view that the Commonwealth has taken.

BREAK.PARA: With respect to any assertions as to numbers that particular people have made, I would simply say: turn to your own state government, my state government—yours and mine is the same state government—and other state governments and ask them to live up to the responsibilities they have got for the provision of legal aid. As to the other part of your question, are we going down the American road, the answer to that is quite simply `no'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, if you will not concede that the legal aid cuts have led to a crisis in the legal aid system, has your attention been drawn further to recent Victorian cases where, for instance, an intellectually disabled woman was forced to represent herself and where two girls were almost cross-examined by their father, who had allegedly sexually abused them, because he had no legal counsel? Are Victoria's legal aid funding cuts that led to the above cases the result of federal funding cuts or is the VLA simply cost cutting? Do you disagree with the president of the Law Council of Australia, Peter Short, who said this morning, `The citizens of Australia shouldn't be the piggy in the middle.' Have you also seen comments from your state Attorney-General in South Australia, Mr Trevor Griffin, who has claimed that the Commonwealth is retreating from its obligations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not seen the comments of Peter Short apparently made this morning—asserted by you as being made this morning.
—I have them right here!

—Fair enough, you have them. I have not seen them. If that is all he said, that citizens should not be the piggy in the middle, I do not think anyone would disagree. I do not see why you think that is of any particular note whatsoever. As to comments made by the state attorney in my own state and presumably shared by a number of other people, what do you imagine, Senator Bolkus, the states are going to say when the Commonwealth says, `Look, it is about time you lived up to your own responsibilities.' Of course the states are going to say, `Look, the Commonwealth is walking away from this, leaving us in the lurch.' Of course the states are going to say that. They have said it for years whenever the Commonwealth has looked to them to come to their side of the bargain in any particular portfolio area, and legal aid is no different. So Trevor Griffin's comments do not surprise me whatsoever. They are the comments I would expect from a state attorney. I would not be at all surprised if other state attorneys had made the same remarks. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, do you agree with the comments made today by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Peter McGauran, that the increased HECS charge for science and engineering courses `has the potential to act as a discouragement to young people entering science and engineering'? Minister, will you give a commitment, like Minister McGauran, to act immediately and, if enrolments are down in these courses, change the differential HECS arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have seen the remarks made by Mr McGauran. Those remarks were made after consultations with me some time ago. I have said in this place on numerous occasions, and I will say it again for your benefit if you were not listening at the time, that of course any sensible government will keep a close watch on the impact of its policy changes. I have clearly indicated that if it turned out that increases in HECS—which I know you are not going to support, in any event—acted as a disincentive such that enrolments in science and engineering were down to a worrying degree, of course we would act.
—They are; they are crashing!

—The enrolments are not settled yet, Senator. You know the enrolments are not settled yet, so why don't you just button up for a minute? Senator, we have made it quite clear that of course we will act. Mr McGauran was then asked if we would wait two or three years to act. His response was no. I concur with that response. We would not wait two or three years to act.

—I have a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. I ask again: do you acknowledge then that HECS may be a disincentive to pursue higher education, especially in those courses? Given that we have already noted that enrolment trends in the science discipline are down overall by 13 per cent, and are down by 19 per cent in science as a co‐discipline with other courses, what further evidence do you need in order to act immediately?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you understand the difference between applications to a university and people who actually end up being enrolled in a particular course. You know that is not yet settled. Perhaps you have not read the Australian today. I do not know whether you did. If you did, you would have seen that it reports that applications to the science faculties at the University of Sydney have increased by five per cent. Senator, you will understand that, in the profiles process, some universities have indicated they expect science to increase; others expect it to go down. You can continue scaremongering, if you like, on the basis of earlier reports. But until this matter is settled there will be no further comment from the government, other than to say that if there is a problem we will, of course, act to fix it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NSW Refugee Advice and Casework Service

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Does the government intend to take any action to ensure advocacy resources to clients of the Refugee Advice and Casework Service in New South Wales—I might say it is a very good body—which has closed following a dispute over funding? I think there are 107 clients involved in that area, but don't hold me to that. Is it true to say that these asylum seekers have been left without advocacy assistance and have, in effect, been put into limbo? Did the Legal Aid Commission's managing director say, `The capacity of my staff has reached its limit,' and, `The most simple solution is obviously to resolve the funding deadlock'? Could whatever action the government intends to take to resolve the funding crisis faced by the Refugee Advice and Casework Service be taken urgently? As the minister would know, these are applicants for asylum status, so they are people who are in a very desperate situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I have some information in relation to this matter. I will give you what information I have. To the extent that more is required, I will ask Mr Ruddock to come back.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand there was a suggestion in a press release by Duncan Kerr a few days ago that Legal Aid New South Wales is under pressure to take over RACS New South Wales cases. It is apparent—if that is what you are referring to, and I think it is—that Mr Kerr does not have all the facts on the matter of applications assistance and contract negotiations within RACS. Funding has not been withdrawn from RACS. At the beginning of November, RACS were advanced funds to continue to supply application assistance until 30 November. RACS has chosen not to draw upon these funds. In addition, RACS has informed the department that they will not accept further detention case referrals. Agreement on contracts for this year has been reached with all contractors other than RACS New South Wales, which has asked for a 10 per cent increase in their unit costs. We are prepared to grant an increase of three per cent, consistent with the increase sought and approved for RACS in Victoria.

We are continuing to negotiate with RACS in good faith and in the proper manner—that is, on a one‐to‐one basis. However, it is increasingly difficult to do so in the very public environment which now exists. We simply cannot negotiate by press release; that is not appropriate. As has been the case throughout this process, we are prepared to continue to seek an appropriate solution. RACS remain responsible for cases on which final decisions have not been made, but for which they have received payment. We have not asked the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales to take over any RACS current cases. Should the situation warrant, we will enter into proper discussions with Legal Aid as one of the agencies funded to provide application assistance services.

That is as much information as I have now, Senator. But if you want more, I will get that answer referred to Mr Ruddock. He can add such as he chooses. If there is any further information you require, I am happy for you to give it to me during the afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The real issue is the situation of the people who are claiming to be asylum seekers. There is some danger in that the dispute between agencies and the government may leave them aside. I would really like to hear from the minister how these asylum seekers can be given the assistance they obviously need to test what is clearly their right not only within Australia but also internationally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The information that I have given you thus far is the best I have at hand, and it was provided fairly recently, but I will go back to Mr Ruddock to see whether there is anything else he can add. It does seem on the basis of that information that the government has been trying to re‐establish a contract with RACS New South Wales. There have been some difficulties. They have been expecting bigger increases than other RACS in other states have got. We certainly hope as a consequence of that that people who do need help are not put at risk. I have indicated in the last part of my answer to you that, while we had not at that point asked the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales to take over cases, should the situation arise, we will enter into discussions with them to see whether they can handle what application assistance services are appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and concerns small business incubators. As we know, small business drives employment growth in Australia. Small business was stymied by red tape and discouraged through high interest rates and the unfair dismissal laws under the previous Labor government. Can the minister inform the Senate of any actions that she has taken to assist the growth of employment through encouraging the successful establishment of new small businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for that question. It was with much pleasure on the weekend that I was able to announce quite extensive funding to 11 new small business incubators, the funding totalling $3.4 million over three years. What the incubators do is provide a common location for new businesses wanting to start up which can access management, marketing and administrative support.

ANSWER.PARA: Through the incubators there is the use of mentors with relevant experience to the new business. This gives some assistance in keeping that business going in the early stages. People are able to draw on the advice of someone in a similar business who has been through similar experiences. One would expect that that sort of mentoring assistance is very valuable and will assist more small businesses that use the incubators to get through that critical 12-month period.

After they are established, the businesses leave the incubator and act as independent businesses on their own, like so many others. More small business incubators means more successful small businesses, and that means more new jobs. Most new small businesses fail within the first five years, and it is believed incubators do something very substantial to reduce that rate of failure, to keep those businesses going and, therefore, to make real jobs in small business.

We all understand that, while big business is important, the generation of new real jobs is likely to come from small and medium sized businesses, and the generation of 11 new small business incubators will go some way at least to enhance those opportunities. After three years, the incubators themselves become independent of the government.

The problem was that Labor ignored the potential of small business. They said a lot about it but did very little for them. They were very anti‐small business. Lots of red tape and the unfair unfair dismissal laws put small business off taking new people on and may have contributed to the fairly large increase in people taking up part-time work. The opportunity for full-time work was not there because of the disincentive of the unfair unfair dismissal law. The coalition recognises that a healthy small business sector will result in employment growth, and it is for that reason that we are prepared to put in $3.4 million over three years to establish 11 new small business incubators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I was asked a question by Senator Childs the other day regarding possible resettlement of any Chinese dissidents living in Hong Kong. I said at the end of my answer that I would refer it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to see whether they had anything further to add. They have now advised me that they have nothing further to add to the answer I gave.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Health Care System in New South WalesEssential Services for Remote Aboriginal CommunitiesDomestic Violence Orders

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I have additional information for three questions that were asked yesterday by Senator Neal, Senator West and Senator McKiernan. I seek leave to have them incorporated into Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR NEAL—26 NOVEMBER 1996
COST SHIFTING—HEALTH SYSTEM IN NEW SOUTH WALES

SENATOR NEAL—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Do you realise that your government's planned $34 million worth of cuts to the New South Wales health care system will mean the closure of 400 hospital beds and the loss of 900 doctor and nursing positions and that this will have a devastating effect on the people of New South Wales?

SENATOR NEWMAN—Claims that the cost shifting penalty to NSW will result in the closure of hospital beds and the loss of medical and nursing positions within the public hospital system are without foundation. Such assertions are merely scare tactics on behalf of the State government.

The method of calculating the penalties balances the long term and short term trends in cost shifting. I refute any claims that any particular State is being singled out—though clearly each State would prefer a method of calculation that favoured its circumstances.
Using this method, NSW adjustment in 1996-97 is $33.4m or 45% of the total $75m adjustment:
. per capita expenditure in NSW under the MBS were 15% higher than the average of all other States in 1995-96; and
. under the diagnostic imaging and radiology parts of the MBS, where there is more scope for cost shifting, per capita expenditure in NSW was 24% higher than the average of all other States.

The cost shifting adjustment represents only 2% of the $1.5b Hospital Funding Grants (HFGs) which will be paid to NSW in 1996-97. Even after this adjustment, HFG payments to NSW in 1996-97 are still 1% higher than they were in 1995-96.

It should also be noted that, even after adjustment is made for the cost shifting penalties, the funding which NSW receives, on a per capita basis, resulting from the Medicare Hospital Funding Agreement, is higher than the average funding which other States receive.

The Commonwealth is proceeding with imposition of the penalties as continued double dipping by the States simply cannot be tolerated. However, there may be some scope for flexibility in the way the measure is implemented. Any reasonable proposal by any State aimed at improving the way the Budget measure has been implemented will be duly considered. The States have been advised by the Department of Health and Family Services that, if they wish to bring forward soundly based proposals for alternative means of allocating the penalties, these will be considered.

All things considered, the States have got off lightly. We have only looked at the growth factors in cost shifting since June 1995 as a baseline point. This is not a reflection of the full extent of cost shifting, nor have we pursued cost shifting over past years.
SENATOR NEAL—How does this proposal sit with Dr Wooldridge's statement in May this year, that:
. . . the Commonwealth would only agree to specific changes to existing arrangements with the State and Territories if . . . the proposed arrangements . . . provide a better deal for service users?
Further, how does your answer accord with Dr Wooldridge's recent statement on ABC radio, that New South Wales is not cost shifting now?

SENATOR NEWMAN—Practices which result in ripping off the wider health system to the tune of $300 million a year can hardly be regarded as providing a better deal for service users. This is precisely what the States have been doing for quite some time now.
The Commonwealth, by its actions in addressing cost shifting activities, is protecting Medicare, which simply could not be sustainable if cost shifting was allowed to continue unfettered.

Moreover, the cost shifting initiative acknowledges features of `best practice', pending possible structural changes in the delivery and financing of ambulatory services generally, in that persons can access services most suitable to their needs and provided in the most convenient environment, whether this be at a public hospital or in the community.

In regard to the Dr Wooldridge's comments on ABC radio, the Honourable Senator is mistaken if she is referring to the 2BL broadcast on 20 November 1996. In that broadcast, the Minister for Health and Family Services said, and I quote, "New South Wales hasn't cost shifted a lot in the last 12 months because there is nothing left to cost shift. They've done it all before. They just did earlier than other states."

Clearly, if New South Wales has stopped cost shifting this will show up in data being provided by doctors from 1 November and such an improved performance will inevitably be reflected in smaller cuts to be made—if indeed any—from NSW or any other State.
26 NOV 96 QUESTION ON NOTICE FROM SENATOR WEST—
On 26 November 1996, Senator West asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence the following questions:
1) When was the Australian Defence Force first informed of the Government's plan to use the Army to assist remote Aboriginal communities?
The answer to the senator's question is:
. Defence was advised on 18 Oct 96 that some members of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation would be meeting with the Prime Minister on 23 Oct 96.

. The Army was requested to advise current capabilities and assistance already being provided to remote area communities. These activities have included water supplies, infrastructure development and health projects.
. Defence participated in the discussions leading up to Minister Herron's announcement on 15 November.
2) What are the financial arrangements relating to this proposal?
The answer to the Senator's question is:
. The Senator's question appears to be based on the misconception that the Army will be conducting widespread construction tasks in remote Aboriginal communities. This is not so.
. The project is designed to enhance ATSIC capabilities to improve water and related health infrastructure by utilising Army expertise in a pilot project in a number of remote communities.

. Discussions are under way with ATSIC and Health and Family Services to identify tasks where this assistance can best be utilised, consistent with the need for community consultation and agreement, and taking account of Army's other tasks.
. It is proposed that the Army's role involve design, project management and participation in projects on the ground in a small number of the most needy communities.
. Army will cover its own salary costs whilst project costs will be met by ATSIC and Health.
3) In particular, what arrangements have been made to supplement Defence for the additional costs?
The answer to the Senator's question is:
. Army will cover its own salary costs whilst project costs will be met by ATSIC and Health. The issue of supplementation therefore does not arise.
4) Given the fact that the Army now contracts out to private firms, will the Army be buying or leasing necessary equipment to assist remote Aboriginal communities?
The answer to the Senator's question is:

. Discussions are under way with ATSIC and Health and Family Services to identify tasks where this assistance can best be utilised, consistent with the need for community consultation and agreement, and taking account of Army's other tasks.
. It is proposed that the Army's role involve design, project management and participation in projects on the ground in a small number of the most needy communities.
. The only costs to Army will be salary costs.
Senator McKiernan asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, without notice, on 26 November 1996:

(1) Whether it was a fact that a law reform researcher with the Federation of Community Legal Centres, Ms Liz Curran, stated that the withdrawal of funding for domestic violence orders occurring as a consequence of the Federal Government's cuts to Legal Aid would put at risk the lives of women and children who face delays while waiting for such orders?

(2) Whether it was a fact that the chairman of the Australian Legal Assistance Board, Mr John King, in a letter to Legal Aid commissioners, stated that such allegations were easily made and often done only to get grants of aid? Does the Minister agree with Mr King's comments?
Senator Newman —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) In the Sunday Age , 24 November 1996, Ms Liz Curran of the Federation of Community Legal Centres, was reported as stating that the withdrawal of funding for domestic violence orders would put at risk the lives of more women and children who would face delays while waiting for such orders in the Family Court.

The Commonwealth discharges its responsibilities in relation to family violence through specific provisions of the Family Law Act. Anyone fleeing violence can apply for a protection order under section 114 of the Family Law Act and urgent ex-parte applications can be made in accordance with Order 12 of the Family Law Rules. The Commonwealth will meet its obligations to provide assistance under its laws and we expect the States and Territories to do the same. The majority of restraining orders are made in accordance with State or Territory law. It is the responsibility of those governments to ensure that those in need of assistance for matters arising under their laws are provided with the means of obtaining access to justice.

(2) The Sunday Age article referred to above also reported Mr John King of the Australian Legal Assistance Board as stating in a letter to Legal Aid commissioners that allegations of domestic violence were easily made and often done to obtain grants of aid.
I strongly disagree with those comments and reaffirm the Government's commitment to assisting victims of domestic violence.
Senator McKiernan also asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women:

Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Health and Family Services will be presenting the 1996 Violence Prevention Awards on December 1996 and will this event proceed? Can you explain whether this event will proceed, given the federal government's neglect of programs which genuinely reduce the threat of families confronted with violence?
Senator Newman: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I do not accept the Honourable Senator's statement that the government has neglected programs in this area. For instance, in the area of Health and Family Services there are a number of initiatives including:

. The National Women's Health Program, which is receiving continued funding this financial year, identifies violence against women as a priority health issue. This program provides resources to address violence against women.

. In addition, the government is currently considering approaches to limit access of potentially violent people to guns. This is a complex area subject to much misconception, and the Minister for Health and Family Services commissioned a group of experts to provide advice to make sure we get it right.

The group was convened by the Australian Institute of Criminology and comprised representatives of leading professional and research organisations in relevant fields. It has now reported on whether evidence exists linking specific health and behavioural conditions and increased risk of aggressive or self-harming behaviour.

The report of the group has implications for a wide range of government portfolios. The Government is considering the recommendations arising from the report and next steps to implement a response to the report.

The findings of this investigation is assisting the working party established by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council which is considering mechanisms for determining mental and physical fitness to own, possess or use a firearm.
