SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to aviation safety.

The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has made a number of decisions since his appointment in March. Two of those decisions were made not in the interests of aviation safety; they were made in order to blatantly reward those who supported them during the recent federal election campaign. They were political paybacks with a sting—a safety sting.

The first decision was to allow the use of portable emergency locater transmitters as well as fixed DLTs. In doing so, Mr Sharp overrode the advice of the technical experts in safety at the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. He also thumbed his nose at the experience and practice of every other country in the world. CASA made a decision to require the use of fixed automatically activating emergency locater transmitters in all aircraft. It was CASA's view that this system offered the best level of safety. It is also the world view. The minister overturned that decision.

This was purely and simply a reward to the Australian Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association for its up-front political support for the coalition during the campaign. CASA had no option but to comply with Mr Sharp's ministerial direction—even though, in my view, it may have placed the organisation in breach of the Civil Aviation Act.

The second decision concerns the imposition on Australia's civil aviation search and rescue units of the precision aerial delivery system—PADS—search and rescue system. In taking this decision, Mr Sharp ignored advice from such experts as the RAAF Aircraft Research and Development Unit. The RAAF unit tested the PADS system in 1995. Let me quote from the summary of the RAAF report. It states:

BREAK.PARA: The PADS system was considered to be unacceptable for release as the first PADS drop resulted in large amplitude rotational motion of the static line and the drog impacting on the elevator of the release aircraft. Consequently, flight testing was suspended.

It is there in the RAAF report in black and white. This equipment was so dangerous it was recommended that it should not even be trialled, let alone put into active service. I asked a number of questions about the problems of the PADS system in recent hearings of the Senate estimates committees. I was advised by a senior officer of Airservices Australia that these deficiencies identified by the RAAF with the new system had been addressed `in the new model'. I was further told:
I have received advice that they have been addressed.
We found out in further questioning that these assurances had come from the company that manufactured them.

The minister then released a media statement on 23 September, announcing that the government had decided to equip Australia's aviation civil search unit with this PADS system. The minister said that there had been an independent evaluation of the PADS system—that is, independent of the RAAF—and that the system was currently in use. The PADS system had been found to be superior. He said:
In 90 days the deployment of the PADS units and training will have been completed providing a final solution and closing the book on this long standing and controversial issue.

The book is far from closed on this issue. The initial PADS training was conducted on 9 and 10 November at Jervis Bay. There were 13 drops of the search and rescue equipment made. I am advised that in seven of these drops—that is, seven out of 13—there were equipment failures, including problems involving the rope and static line. This is the equipment that the minister had independently evaluated and has spent nearly $700,000 of public money on.

I understand the particular incident that saw an aircraft nearly lost involved not an equipment failure but a breakdown in procedure. It appears that the government has chosen to ignore the advice from the RAAF Aircraft Research and Development Unit but the release altitude for PADS of 100 feet—that is above the water—is unsafe. I understand that the aircraft that was involved in this incident was operating at an altitude of 100 feet when it got into difficulty. At that altitude, there is clearly no margin whatever for error. The failure of the government to accept the RAAF advice had put the crew on board this aircraft at risk, and the minister should be held accountable.

I understand that the use of PADS, having spent $700,000 on it, has now been suspended and that aviation civil search units have been directed to revert to the existing Airservices Australia SAR systems. These systems have only a one-year currency, and a number of the units are now reaching the end of their use-by date.

The Aviation Civil Search Organisation in Australia is now under threat of collapse as a result of this political fix—all because the minister is indulging himself in a political pay-off. There are a number of outstanding answers to questions I asked in the estimates hearings about both the ELT issue and the PADS issue, which I am advised have now been sitting on the minister's desk for more than two weeks. He has simply ignored the deadline for those answers, which was 11 November. I can only conclude at this stage that it is because the answers he has sitting on his desk are not to his liking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman, Sen Dominic

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senator Mackay and Senator Panizza today, relating to Australian National.

In his answers today, Senator Alston continued to exaggerate the circumstances that Australian National finds itself in. He was trying to shift the attention away from the bottom line of AN's operations and attack the opposition for being irresponsible. It is very irresponsible for the government to continue to mislead the community and keep information to themselves about the true circumstances of Australian National.

There has clearly been a long-term plan by the government to discredit Australian National so that they can justify its sale to private interests. This has been an ideological exercise aimed at making sure that this government can show off its privatisation credentials. All of the facts about AN should be put on the table, not just the selected facts that we have been given access to. The government's secrecy about the future of AN has been outrageous. It is obvious that they have been planning to sell it all along.

The Brew report, or what we saw of it in September, estimated that AN's losses for the 1995-96 financial year would be between $135 million and $148 million. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, told the Sunday program last weekend that it would be $250 million. The minister did not mention, however, that over half of the claimed losses is accounted for by the write‐down value of some AN assets due to an asset revaluation program. Then there is the money that is accounted for redundancies and other abnormal costs. The truth is that AN has done a bit better than the Brew report predicted in so far as its accounts are concerned for 1995-96.

Today Senator Alston alleged that the opposition was quibbling about how the debt was constructed. The fact is that this parliament has every right to know about the financial circumstances of AN. It has an obligation to the community to make you come clean about the motives. Then there is the $50 million set aside for potential clean‐up activities, which adds to AN's overall liabilities.

Senator Mackay asked a very reasonable question about this and received a very unconvincing answer. Are there any other possible contingencies that the government can tack on to the liabilities list? The reality is that $50 million would only be used for the clean‐up of sites after they were no longer a part of the rail system, and that could be in many years time. The difficulties encountered by AN have been exploited and exaggerated by this government in an effort to make it look as though the end of the publicly owned rail service is nigh. The truth is that AN has a bright future if it is left to its own plans and allowed to develop its own business.

My experience with AN workers and their unions has shown me that there is a real commitment to ensuring that rail becomes more profitable and efficient. The government has apparently begun a campaign to try to convince the electorate that this sell off is a rebirth for rail. But if $200 billion is set aside for redundancies and leave entitlement payouts, what is the future of jobs in rail? To say that Port Augusta and Launceston are going to be better off because of the privatisation of rail is to refuse to accept all the evidence and previous experience.

These communities need new industries on top of what is already there. The local members who participated in the government backbench committee on this issue should hang their heads in shame. They have betrayed the people who they promised to represent. They have allowed the decline of their own communities to occur without putting up a fight and questioning what they were told.

This government has shown its contempt for rail workers and their families by playing their lies for their own political ends. They have also shown a disregard for this parliament by their selective presentation of the facts about Australian National.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in the debate on the motion moved by Senator Foreman. The only real praise that Senator Foreman could provide to AN was that they had done a little bit better. That is hardly wholesome praise, is it? He said that they did a little bit better than had originally been anticipated. The reality is that they have done shockingly over many years. That is, unfortunately, the result of government neglect which we, as a new incoming government, are now addressing.

ANSWER.PARA: We were told by Senator Foreman that somehow we have contempt for the lives of railway workers. Senator Foreman, through you, Mr Deputy President, allow me to remind you that when you people came into office there were some 9,200 railway workers in this country. There are now slightly under 3,000, about 2,500. You looked after them really well, didn't you? That is a fantastic record of looking after railway workers!

The reality is that we were left with a mess. We have to clean it up and we have to deal with it in such a way that not only the railway workers are guaranteed a future but, more importantly, the whole network itself is guaranteed a future. If we continue along the path that has been suggested by the Labor Party, we would be in a situation where we would be subsidising each and every rail worker in this country to the tune of $220,000 per annum. What a great scheme! Let it keep going and ballooning out and ballooning out. Let it cost the taxpayer not hundreds of thousands, not millions, but in fact billions of dollars. Really, it was an unsustainable situation. I think Senator Foreman knows that in his heart of hearts.

In relation to the workers, all their full entitlements have been guaranteed and they will be protected. He asks why we have made a provision of $112 million for redundancies. The reason is that, as anybody who knows anything about AN and the work force knows, there is an accrued liability on average of $55,000 per railway employee in relation to redundancy. That is something that is well known by those who know something about the industry. Anybody who would want to take over the workers who are currently employed would not necessarily want to take those employees over with that redundancy liability in place.

Therefore, what is going to in fact occur, I believe, is that a lot of these railway workers will get a redundancy and the very next day be re‐employed. Therefore, those railway workers will be very well looked after and their local regional communities will have the extra injection of funds into those communities through, on average, $55,000 per employee.

We are also criticised for the environmental clean‐up. It stands to reason that if you pass over a business to private enterprise then the environmental liability has to be looked after as well. We in Tasmania have the former Inveresk rail yard. That was part of the Labor Party's better cities program which we have honoured and committed ourselves to. Part of the problem when we started developing the site was the environmental clean‐up, as I am sure Senator O'Brien would acknowledge, because past practices were not environmentally sound. We have made provision for that as well.

It does not matter how the Labor Party seeks to address this problem. The reality is that AN was in a mess. It was getting worse by the day and we have taken the tough decision to clean up the rail system for the benefit of all Australians, particularly for the rail workers whose futures were in doubt and who will now be secure because of the restructuring that we propose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this motion I want to say: isn't it remarkable that when you want figures to jump out of nowhere and support your arguments they appear? Isn't it remarkable that you include in those figures matters which seem to have suddenly ballooned and seem to suddenly be relevant? One would have to assume that all of the accountants prior to the recent re‐accounting of AN's books got it wrong—that suddenly, at a time when the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) is announcing a policy, out of the ground jump these new figures with all of these issues that were never previously considered. They are now valid. What are you trying to do, Senator Abetz? Talk down the price?

ANSWER.PARA: Is that what the purpose of the exercise is? Do you want to say that it is worth less because it has got more debts so you can talk down the price? Is there some ulterior motive in this? Just as we have had a lot of misleading information from this government in a number of areas—be it Telstra, the Wright family, or whatever—this is another case of manufacturing the evidence for your own case and then saying it often enough so that people will believe you.

One of the issues that I would like to hear addressed at some time—I am sure Senator Abetz will find the time to address this matter—is how this government again has got the matter wrong as to what it has to do to achieve the sale. TALK.START.PARA: —A few more than you.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I do need to remind you, Senator Abetz: it is clearly the case that you do not have the numbers. You just have a few deals with the Greens to keep you in office for a temporary period.

ANSWER.PARA: Without the decision of the Tasmanian parliament, the federal government cannot sell the tracks and obviously the land that the tracks are on. TALK.START.PARA: —You are well acquainted, aren't you?
—No, of course it is not Mowbray.
—No, it is not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The locomotive yards in Launceston are the only yards that provide any service to whoever is going to operate any system in the future. In fact, they have been engaged recently in some very important work upgrading the locomotive fleet. All that will be able to be sold is that fleet. I am told those workshops are intended to be sold off, perhaps to be used for future residential redevelopment land.

ANSWER.PARA: Here we have a situation where, again, we have some fumbled figures by the minister. We clearly have a situation where the Tasmanian part of the operation, as envisaged by the minister, cannot be sold, certainly not without the support of the Tasmanian parliament—as distinct from the Tasmanian government, it being a minority government.

The minister has got it wrong. We have a whole lot of figures that keep jumping out of the ground to justify what the minister is doing. Perhaps he should go back and do his homework again. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to address on the Australian National issue. They mostly arose out of what Senator Foreman had to say in his delivery on this matter. He made two points. One was that there was an unnecessary $50 million going into an environmental clean‐up fund or sinking fund—whatever you would like to call it—and the other was that the trading figures are lessened. But the fact is that the figures allow for depreciation. As most senators in this chamber who have been in business, and those who have not been in business, should know, two principles stand out: to keep a successful business running—if you want to keep it moving and not let it run into liquidation—you allow for depreciation and also any contingent liabilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us address the environment. As to the environment liability, whether the rail is owned by National Rail or a private rail, the pigeons will come home to roost when the clean‐up is to be done. With rail systems, whether they be private or public—and even if this one remains in the public domain—some clean‐up has to happen.
I have a good example. I fly into Adelaide every Sunday afternoon, and it seems they are cleaning up Mile End, which is a state rail property. You can see that that rail is no longer needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous government's better cities money is fixing that up.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am using that as an example of land being cleaned up if it is no longer used. In Kalgoorlie, for instance, there is a lot of National Rail land that is not being used by National Rail any more. Because of the efficiencies that exist in rail systems, you do not need the land that you used to need some time back. Whether it is going to be retained by National Rail in the public domain or sold off as an ongoing situation, some clean‐up does have to occur. Of course, if it is sold off as an ongoing situation and if the $50 million is not in the sinking fund, that will depress the price of the sell off. So you just cannot get away from that $50 million. It is there. If you do not allow for it when you sell off, that is $50 million less you are going to get for your business. Otherwise, if you have it there, you use it. So the result is the same.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator O'Brien interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is, Senator O'Brien. When you come to the point of depreciation, if you want to keep a business going, it may require a lot of plant—and railways have rolling stock and locomotives. Unless you just want to go into liquidation or sell out for whatever you can get in the end, because the value of the assets and liabilities is getting fairly close together, anyhow, if you do not allow for depreciation, even in the smallest of businesses, such as a sandwich shop, with sandwich makers and bread cutters, one day there will be a lot of plant to replace.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Foreman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you haven't allowed for it, as Senator Foreman said, it is because of the depreciation allowance. If you do not allow for it, one day you will get into trouble. So that is the idea. That is why I stood up—to tell Senator Foreman what the situation is. The depreciation figure has got to be there and the liability figure has got to be there.
—How many years do you depreciate a rail system over?
—That I do not know. But for a locomotive, my guess would be—
—Thirty years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not 30 years. My guess would be 10 years, and rolling stock, et cetera. But I do not want to extend the debate. That is what I wanted to say, on those two business principles. I do not think anyone, even if you have not been in business, can deny that they do not have to be looked at.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Bolkus proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to honour its pre‐election commitment to maintain funding for legal aid.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start with a couple of quotations. The first one is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not an overstatement to say that the system of administering justice is in crisis. Ordinary people cannot afford to enforce their rights or to litigate to protect their immunities. To that extent, the coercive force of the law is undermined.

This grim prognosis of the state of our legal system is not mine. The words are those of the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Gerard Brennan, and they come from a speech he gave earlier this year to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration in Wellington. His Honour's views on the consequences of the decisions made by the current government also make sombre reading. He said:

The settlement of disputes by legal process is a fundamental function of government in a society under the rule of law. If the function is not performed, the law is not applied and the festering sore of injustice spreads the infection of self‐help. Power is then unrestrained by law. Peace and order are at risk and, sometimes, tragedy may be the consequence. Laws that are put on the statute book mock the integrity of the political process unless the beneficiaries of those laws can enforce them.

Let us put this crisis into perspective. At no time in recent political history has an Australian government made such a sustained attack on the right of access by ordinary Australians to our legal system. All in all, the federal budget contained some $320 million worth of measures that will deny many tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of Australians access to justice. The most obvious of these are the dramatic cuts in legal aid funding and the imposition of unnecessarily high court fees. But the government has also cut a raft of smaller measures that, in their own way, will have just as devastating an effect on access to justice. To get it into perspective, the government has cut back twice the amount of money provided by Labor in last year's much lauded Justice Statement. It is a breach of commitment. Before the election, the coalition promised to:

. . . match and extend Labor's commitment to access to justice measures . . . We make a commitment to . . . the achievement of a justice system that is accessible to all Australians, regardless of their means.
More specifically, in the case of legal aid, the coalition promised:
A Liberal and National Government will maintain current levels of legal aid funding and funding to community legal centres.

Those promises are now worthless. The breach of those promises will have real and devastating consequences in relation to the fundamental rights that should be enjoyed by all Australians. As the Chief Justice stated, and I think we should all agree, `access to justice is a fundamental function of government in a society under the rule of law'.

The first and most devastating cut has been to legal aid funding: some $120 million over three years, commencing in July 1997. Most importantly, the Commonwealth has also stated that from July next year none of the legal aid funding to be provided by the Commonwealth will be allowed to be spent on matters other than those arising under Commonwealth law. That in itself is grave enough; but it gets even worse. At a Senate estimates committee hearing, the Secretary to the Attorney‐General's Department, Mr Skehill, admitted that not all matters arising under Commonwealth law would receive funding and that priority would be given to some matters over others. He also refused to elaborate on what those priorities would be. To go even further, when asked, Mr Skehill said:

BREAK.PARA: The decision to reduce the funding
and to make it available only for expenditure on matters arising under Commonwealth law is non‐negotiable.

This decision is contrary to reports of and evidence provided at inquiries undertaken over the years. It flies very much in the face of some 26 years of practice in this country for the Commonwealth government to assume responsibility for a whole raft of matters and to provide funding to states for matters arising under state laws. This decision has been made by the government without consultation, without review and without any understanding of its implications.

If there had been a broader review and a more systematic approach taken to this, the government would have overcome some enormous problems. For instance, they would have overcome the problem they faced at a meeting with state and territory attorneys‐general on 25 October this year at which they not only slammed the federal government's decision but also basically indicated that the whole structure of legal aid in this country is being threatened by the Commonwealth government's unilateral decision to review funding.

To compound the irrationality of this decision, at that meeting the Commonwealth Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) admitted that the figures upon which the Commonwealth had based its decision were flawed. Yet, he publicly refused to announce that he would reconsider the decision or even the level of funding involved. This is not just a case of a lack of review or lack of recognition of need, but also an admission by the Commonwealth government that they messed it up. Even after that admission, they made no undertaking to go back and review the mistake they had made.

We do have a crisis here. The crisis we have in Australia is not just in respect of the legal aid system. It is also in respect of the whole legal system, as Chief Justice Brennan made clear. These cuts are already having devastating consequences, particularly for migrants, the unemployed, recipients of pensions, students, veterans, the disabled and victims of human rights abuses. They will all find it much more difficult, if not impossible, to receive justice.

The Law Council of Australia held a forum in the old Parliament House this morning and they had representatives of all sectors of the community from just about all over Australia. It is a pity that members of the government were not there to hear some of the problems currently faced by the legal aid system. That forum agreed to a communique, which stated that the participants call upon the government to meet with a delegation to hear first-hand of community concerns.
This has not happened as yet.

Secondly, the participants call upon the government to recommit to the concept of provision of legal aid as an essential element in providing access to justice and acknowledge the adverse consequences to other government expenditure of cuts to legal aid. That point acknowledges that legal aid is essential not as charity but as a right in our society and also reflects the fact that many of the savings here are going to be false savings.

Thirdly, the participants also call on the government to recommit to the principle of equality before the law. As Mr Peter Short, the President of the Law Council of Australia, said this morning, equality before the law has been something we have been fighting for since the Magna Carta. We should not give up the fight now because of financial restraint.

The communique also calls on the federal government to reverse the decision to cut legal aid funding and to enter into meaningful discussions and negotiations with the states and territories to ensure that legal aid in the Commonwealth of Australia is appropriately funded; in other words, to show some leadership and assume the responsibility that for 2½ decades at least some governments in this country have taken and assumed.

There was one particular aspect of this morning's proceedings that I would like to dwell on now, that is, the role and the rights of women and the plight of women as a consequence of this decision. They were stressed amongst all other problems that will flow from this decision. In particular, the speaker from the National Women's Justice Coalition, Judy Harrison, made the point that some 100,000 women would be directly affected by these decisions taken by the federal government—as I say, decisions that were taken without consultation.

It will not just be women affected by matters arising under state provisions for domestic violence but those seeking justice in terms of criminal injury compensation, those involved in de facto property settlements, those involved in acts of discrimination against them under state law, those claiming compensation, those involved in credit and consumer rights issues, those involved in tenancy issues and those who will be declined assistance in family law because of the necessary decline in available funding. Children will also be affected. All these areas will be affected by the government's decision to cut back funding in this area. We are talking about 100,000 women directly affected and we are talking about a part of our community which report after report has recognised as being treated unfairly by our justice system.

The Prime Minister himself is committed to reducing incidents of domestic violence. This government, when in opposition before the election, acknowledged that women are treated unequally in terms of the legal system and that there is an imbalance in the legal aid system with respect to women. This decision by this government will more deeply affect the rights of women and basically accentuate the imbalance that is in the system now.

Judy Harrison said that 30 per cent of recipients of grants in the legal aid system are women. But let us take into account that they are more often than not victims of domestic violence. The cuts will put women's safety at risk. Indigenous women have domestic homicide rates at appallingly high levels, but ATSI funding is not enough. The legal aid system discriminates against women, as the ALRC has determined in its most recent report. All these matters were matters raised this morning, and it is a pity that the government was not there to hear them. I am glad we have been able to bring them to the Senate this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that this government continues to honour the sentiments outlined in its pre-election commitments to legal aid funding. Let us just go back to the policy document and remind ourselves of what the coalition committed itself to. What it said it would do is increase the extent to which legal aid is granted in civil proceedings, particularly in the family area, and explore ways of ensuring equity in the allocation of legal assistance and in devising new and innovative ways of ensuring that all Australians are able to access the court system.

SPEECH.PARA: In that statement the coalition went on to recognise that governments simply do not have adequate funds to assist those who want and merit legal assistance. Consequently, alternative solutions need to be found. In that statement the coalition was alluding to the fact that, prior to the election, funding for legal aid was a problem, that obviously not everybody who wanted or needed legal aid could be funded. That is simply a fact of life. This government has in no way turned itself away from the fact that all are equal before the law.

Since coming to government in March this year this government discovered the $8 billion black hole which needed to be addressed. So legal aid, just like all other areas of government funding, had to experience a cutback. The government also became aware that the existing legal aid agreements with the states were no longer appropriate. It has been some 10 years since these agreements were looked at and they needed to be renegotiated. The government is currently in the process of renegotiating those agreements. For Senator Bolkus to say that the government is not talking to the states is quite simply not true.

It is also not true to say that the cuts are having drastic consequences because the cuts have not yet taken place. In fact the cuts that have been mentioned do not take place until the next financial year. Any cuts or any lack of legal aid funding now is as a result of the previous government's decisions.

I also take issue with Senator Bolkus on another matter, that the government is not consulting. The Senate legal and constitutional committee, of which Senator Bolkus is a member, is looking at a wide ranging reference into legal aid and the government is also undertaking a detailed study of legal aid. That study is to be completed by December this year.

But let us look at the undertaking the coalition made in relation to civil and family law. We need only look back at the figures to see that between 1990‐91 and 1994‐95 Commonwealth funding for legal aid increased by 6.3 per cent in real terms. Over the same period, the number of approved applications for assistance in family law matters funded by legal aid commissions fell by 19 per cent.

Although the Commonwealth was expending more money on legal aid, we had a decrease in funding for family law matters. Therefore, the Commonwealth was not getting value for its legal aid dollar. So the Commonwealth decided that it should fund only legal aid matters. That would thereby ensure an increase in funding for family law matters. That, of course, is what was stated in the coalition's election policy. There is absolutely no question of the government failing to honour any commitment in that regard.

In the fiscal environment in which we find ourselves, which was inherited from the previous government, it is only proper to allocate costs between the Commonwealth and the states as needed. Senator Bolkus has referred to various jurisdictions which are state matters—such things as de facto relationships, restraining orders, courts of petty sessions and largely criminal matters. The Commonwealth is saying the states can take care of state matters and the Commonwealth will take care of Commonwealth matters. Indeed, the Commonwealth is currently responsible for providing more than 50 per cent of funding for legal aid commissions and provides additional funding to legal aid commissions for child support matters, war veterans' matters and criminal cases arising under the Commonwealth law.

PARA.BREAK: The Commonwealth's priorities for assistance are largely in the areas of family and civil law. These are the matters that I men tioned earlier were stated in the coalition policy. The Commonwealth has therefore, for all intents and purposes, been subsidising the states and territories for matters which have largely been in the state jurisdiction. The Commonwealth, as I said, has determined that in future it will fund only Commonwealth matters. Of course, funding levels for those Commonwealth matters will be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has said a lot in relation to legal aid, mainly portraying doom and gloom. The government does not shy away from the fact that we could always spend more money on legal aid. I am a great proponent of the legal aid system in this country. I believe the legal aid commissions we have in various states function very well, and any cut in this area has to be made with a great deal of thought and care. It is not something the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) relishes, but it is a fact of life that we cannot spend money that we do not have. People do not rely on Bankcard for their household finances. To do so would be irresponsible.

We have a duty, not only to this generation but to forthcoming generations, to put Australia's finances in order. If we continue to go down the slippery slide the previous government was going down, in years to come we simply will not have a legal aid system. We have a legal aid system that we can be proud of, one which I think no other country can boast. But if we are to keep it we have to be financially responsible now and we have to look to the future. If we look after the money now, we will be able to extend into those areas which need attention in later years.

The government is negotiating these legal aid agreements with various state governments. The government has maintained that it will fund only Commonwealth matters, but negotiations are still on foot. Senator Bolkus has implied that the door has closed, but that is simply not so. Over the forthcoming months the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee will be looking at the reference into legal aid which I mentioned earlier. The national legal aid conference held today was attended by representatives from the government. I think Mr Reaburn, the first assistant secretary of the department, was there with other officers. So the government did have representation at that conference today. The government will look at the comments and submissions made at that conference, as will the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee.

The government has acted responsibly and has approached this matter with great care. It does not make any cutback with any relish whatsoever. I do not believe that we will in any way be facing the abrogation of equality before the law that Senator Bolkus makes out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can begin by correcting Senator Ellison. Commissions have had to make cuts now because some cases can run over two budgetary periods and they cannot take the risk that cases at hand will run out of money. So it does not mean that the cuts to come have not had an immediate effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats support what Senator Bolkus has put forward for discussion as a matter of public importance. We strongly believe that the federal government should retain responsibility for funding legal aid. First, and most obviously, the coalition parties made a pre-election promise to maintain funding for legal aid. Law and Justice, the government's key policy document, states:
. . . a Liberal and National Government will: maintain current levels of legal aid funding and funding to community legal aid centres.
You have broken that promise. The principles behind this, the document goes on to say, are that:

. . . the maintenance of the rule of the law is basic to our democratic system. The fundamental tenets of the Liberal and National Parties' approach to law and justice are, amongst other things, that:
. all people should be equal before the law;
. all people regardless of status or financial means should have the ability to access the law;
. the law must be accessible

I think you have broken those promises as well. Has the government changed its mind? Is this merely rhetoric? Cutting $120 million from legal aid over the next three years certainly will not guarantee that all people are equal before the law and will not guarantee that all people will have access to the law and/or to justice regardless of their economic circumstances.

What this government's economic policies guarantee is that those who are extremely rich will have access to justice. The majority of Australians will be denied access to the law and to justice simply because they will not be able to afford it. Secondly, access to justice is a crucial component of a functioning participatory democracy. Could we imagine our country denying a person access to justice simply because they were unable to afford it? Each and every citizen has a right to access the legal system.

Thirdly, the Democrats contend that cases funded by legal aid should play a role in the funding of test cases. We say that test cases are those cases which are never likely to proceed to court. They are often cases involving high degrees of risk, as they involve issues never before tested in the courts, yet they are of crucial importance in testing the ability of the judicial system to adapt and change. In most instances, solicitors and barristers will take on cases in which they are likely to receive a deferred payment but are less likely to take on a case on a speculative basis. Legal aid is therefore vital to cases that might otherwise never go to court.
Fourthly, the access to justice reports all refer to the importance of legal aid for the special needs of disadvantaged groups. I quote from the access to justice action plan:
The most obvious barrier [to justice] is the financial one. This, of course, affects many people in the community, especially in times of high unemployment.

The Law Council of Australia's national summit on legal aid was held today. The following facts were noted by distinguished speakers, including Ms Judy Harrison, spokesperson for the Women's Justice Coalition; Graeme Evans, of the Australian Council of Social Services; Helen Bayes, national convener for the Defence of Children International; and the Reverend Harry Herbert, the general secretary of the Uniting Church Board of Social Responsibility.

Here are some facts. It has been estimated that 60,000 people will miss out on legal aid next year. Probably less than 15 per cent of Australians currently have access to legal aid. Last year in Western Australia, 70 per cent of the people who applied for legal aid were denied it, and that is under the old system. The section of the Attorney-General's Department that administers legal aid received a 6.6 per cent pay increase. There have been cases reported of adolescent children having to interpret for their mothers in protection applications where there has been domestic violence.

Access to legal aid is decided on two bases: a means test and a `worthiness' test, which involves a subjective analysis of the case. Presently, for someone to qualify for full legal aid, they have to be earning less than $128 per week. The cuts will have a disastrous effect upon women in domestic violence situations. On the other side of the coin, because of the High Court's decision in the Dietrich case, serious criminals will not proceed to trial without representation. Because of the decision in re Kay, important custody, access and protection issues may not proceed with regard to children.

Part of living in a democracy means having a vital and well funded judiciary. Legal aid is an integral component in gaining access to justice for those most disadvantaged in our society. Without it, the law becomes a farce. Without legal aid, more indigenous people will end up in custody. Figures revealing the increasing number of deaths in custody released this week are very sobering. Does the government really want to be responsible for ensuring that more and more indigenous Australians end up in gaol cells or at the coroner's court?

Something else has now come to our attention. We have just been informed of federal cutbacks to the corporate watchdog, the ASC. With regard to the Australian Securities Commission, the Western Australian Director of Public Prosecutions, John McKechnie QC, said that this area of cutbacks will result in the advancement and support of white collar crime. This illustrates the same point as those mentioned earlier with regard to legal aid cutbacks. When governments remove the mechanisms that are designed to make the public and private sector accountable, they create a vacuum in which corruption can prosper and grow. We saw this in Western Australia in the 1980s with WA Inc. This recent move by the federal government sets the pace for similar public corruption. Political parties who weaken government accountability are just as culpable as subsequent governments or previous ones that have corrupt elements within them.

How about a few more facts. Lawyers of various types in this country number 40,732. There are 683 QCs and SCs and 767 judges. Fifty-one out of 224 MPs in this parliament are lawyers—that is 23 per cent—but half of the cabinet are lawyers. That makes for an awful lot of approbating and reprobating. I say about this government that you do not have to be conservative to lack imagination. You are doing nothing to attack the cost of justice or provide vision in this area. Forcing all people out of the public purse, which is legal aid, into the private pockets of the law firms is not good for this country.

—The honourable senator opposite talks about tax deductibility. SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the impact of the planned Commonwealth cuts to the provision of access to legal aid. In particular, I would like to point out the disastrous implications that this move would have on Tasmania. The Legal Aid Commission of Tasmania provides one of the most effective legal aid services in the country. This service provides legal advice, a duty solicitor and legal representation, phone advice and valuable community education for the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: In the lead-up to the federal election the coalition promised to `match and extend Labor's commitment to access to justice measures'. That was in the coalition's policy document entitled `Law and justice for all of us'. But it would appear that that is just another of the coalition government's broken promises, or shall we refer to them as non-core promises?

It appears that the intent of this government is to reduce the level of access to justice measures. It appears that the coalition government intends to renege on its commitment to `the achievement of a justice system that is accessible to all Australians, regardless of their means'. That was in the same statement. This comes as no surprise for it seems to me that the coalition is committed to reneging on nearly all of the commitments it made to maintaining services, particularly in my state of Tasmania.
I would like to refer senators to the February 1996 Liberal and National parties' law and justice policy. This policy states:
A Liberal and National government will maintain current levels of legal aid funding as well as funding to community legal centres. In government we will:
. examine ways, in consultation with the Legal Aid Commissions, of increasing the extent to which legal aid is granted in civil proceedings, particularly in the family law area; and
. explore ways of ensuring equity in the allocation of legal assistance and in devising new and innovative ways of ensuring that all Australians are able to access the court system.

That was February. By June this year, not four months later, the situation had changed. On 28 June this year the Commonwealth Attorney-General (Mr Williams) gave notice to all Australian legal aid commissions that contracts for funding would have to be renegotiated effective from 1 July 1997. The standard Commonwealth government contribution is 55 per cent of the total government contribution. In Tasmania the Commonwealth contribution is 60 per cent.

There are many reasons why Tasmania receives a slightly higher level of funding. I would like to take the opportunity now to discuss those reasons. Forty-five thousand Tasmanian people access legal aid in all areas of the law every year. These clients are able to access services only after completing a strict assets and income test. Over 80 per cent of persons granted legal aid in Tasmania are in receipt of some form of Commonwealth benefit. Tasmania has 15 per cent more people receiving Commonwealth benefits than the Australian average. I rely upon the `Australian demographic statistics' of December 1995 from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for those statistics.

Tasmania is also in the unenviable position of having the highest unemployment level of any state. This is from the same statistics. The average income for Tasmanians is the lowest in the country. The average weekly income for a Tasmanian family is $620 compared with the New South Wales average of over $740. That is from the Australian Bureau of Statistics `Household expenditure and characteristics by state' statistics.

All of this means that there are more Tasmanians who qualify for legal aid. The stated intention of the Attorney-General to place emphasis on Commonwealth law matters, rather than people for whom the Commonwealth has a special responsibility, will lead many pensioners and other benefit recipients to be without a safety net if legal problems arise.

A further complication for Tasmanian people is the high level of decentralisation. More than half of the Tasmanian population live outside the capital city. This is the highest level of decentralisation of any state in the nation. To effectively service this decentralised population, Tasmania is required to have four branches of legal aid services. People living outside capital cities should not suffer in terms of access to service. If Tasmania is to receive equitable funding, there must be a realisation of the special hardships facing the people of Tasmania, and the previous arrangements recognise those.

Yet despite the additional difficulties that Tasmania faces in terms of provision of legal aid services, Tasmania still manages to have one of the highest levels of service in the country. It is a fast, effective service with sound management. Any reduction in funding could put this effective service at risk. Regional Tasmania has already seen the closure of CES branches and the closure of family law courts, both services that the coalition promised to maintain. The people of Tasmania cannot continue to have their services slashed by this government without effect.
The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has long claimed that he is here for the battlers—that he must demonstrate a commitment to the battlers of Australia. He said:

It is an important signal from the Liberal Party to the rest of the Australian community of just how important it is for us to demonstrate a commitment to the entire Australian community. To demonstrate a commitment to the battlers of Australian society.

He said that in a post‐budget address in Sydney on 16 May. I would like to tell the Prime Minister that those battlers that he claims to represent in Tasmania are not going to see the attack on their legal aid service as a demonstrated commitment. It is a clear breach of coalition policy, it is an even clearer of breach of the coalition's election promises and it is a blatantly clear message to the people of Tasmania that their needs are irrelevant to this government.
On 14 August this year the Prime Minister, in an interview on Sydney radio 2UE, was asked about the reactions that the battlers would be having after the budget. The Prime Minister answered:
Well, the battler will be saying; Howard kept his faith . . .

I ask the government to demonstrate that they intend to keep faith with the people who rely on the legal aid service and to honour their pre-election commitment to maintain funding levels for legal aid, because if they do not, they will stand condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to be expected that all of us who are concerned about access to justice for those in need in the community will express concern at any perceived threat to reduction in the availability of legal aid. The proposals put forward by the government, however, deserve constructive and careful consideration before reaction degenerates into hysteria, false alarm and exaggerated predictions about the number of people directly affected now or likely to be affected by adjustments which have not yet come into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the changes that the government have announced will ensure that legal assistance for matters arising under the Commonwealth law will be maintained, and the states and territories will assume responsibility for legal aid arising under their own state and territory laws.

Now, there is nothing sinister about this decision. The Commonwealth decision has been prompted by the disproportionate amount of funding which has been applied by the states and territories to meeting demands for legal aid in state law matters, such as criminal trials, at the expense of Commonwealth matters such as family law, child support, eligibility for benefits under Commonwealth laws such as pension matters and aid for war veterans.

The Commonwealth, very simply, is removing an unjustified subsidy to the states and territories for their own legal matters. It is simply unacceptable and unfair to those needing legal aid in our community to deal with Commonwealth laws and matters when, in circumstances that currently prevail, state funding and administration by state legal aid commissions take an unfair amount of the funding.

The Commonwealth has estimated that around $33 million of the $150 million appropriated by the Commonwealth for legal aid is currently diverted from Commonwealth matters and is being applied to state and territory law matters, predominantly criminal trials. But as well as getting Commonwealth funding, the states and territories are able to access further moneys from the statutory interest on solicitors' trust accounts.

With the extent of Commonwealth funding to the states and the use of the statutory interest on solicitors' trust accounts, the states have been able to reduce their contributions to legal aid to an unacceptably low percentage of the legal aid bill. It is high time that the states and territories faced up to funding their own fair share in the provision of legal aid to the needy.

It is ironic indeed that Senator Bolkus is the mouthpiece today—and Senator O'Brien—of the outrage at the Commonwealth's proposals to bring proper balance and fairness into the distribution of legal aid in this country. How can it be fair that people with family law, associated domestic violence problems and other Commonwealth disputes are squeezed out, unable to get assistance to deal with Commonwealth laws, because the legal aid commissions in each state have been able to spend most of their funds on state and territory criminal matters? Where is the fairness in that?

PARA.BREAK: After all, it was the late former Senator Lionel Murphy who, in 1973, used the consti tutional device of designating certain categories of persons as having sufficient connection with the Commonwealth to attract Commonwealth funding and established the Australian Legal Aid Office. Those categories—pensioners, migrants, students, service men and women and Aborigines—had hitherto been assisted by the private legal profession funded by interest on the statutory trust accounts in each state.

SPEECH.PARA: All that is now proposed is that, where these categories of eligible persons have a Commonwealth law problem, the Commonwealth will fund them; where they have a state law matter, the states and territories will be expected to fund aid. An exception is the abolition of the separate Aboriginal Legal Service, recently so much criticised in connection with failure to adequately represent indigenous people, and the transfer of that funding to the state and territory legal aid commissions.

Senator Murray is not here to hear this, but that may do something constructive to assist with the appalling toll of Aboriginal deaths in custody. The current system is certainly not helping them. Senator Murray also mentioned need for a bit of vision. How is this for a bit of vision? One may ask, why not take this opportunity to reconsider the whole gamut of legal aid services and how those services are funded? It is not as though the current legal aid system has worked so efficiently that it should be immune from creative and new ideas to deal with this most fundamental of rights—access to justice.

There is a legal aid industry out there with practitioners dependent on legal aid funding to maintain their professional practices. These circumstances provide an ideal opportunity for the state legal aid commissions to introduce some innovative practices and efficiencies into this industry. A recent call by the Queensland Legal Aid Commission for tenders from the private profession to undertake trial work in blocks of criminal cases in Brisbane, Cairns and Southport has the potential to introduce competition and to hold down costs in legal aid work. New South Wales has also indicated a willingness to try tendering.

BREAK.PARA: A franchise system similar to that operating in the United Kingdom is being tried in Victoria. Legal firms meeting audit requirements are eligible to tender for work, at set prices. Obviously, it is too early to tell whether such innovations will be effective not only to deliver aid but also to deliver it in a cost-effective and responsible way. But the incentive is there and, if the states and territories meet their own responsibilities in their own jurisdictions, the total funding available to legal aid will remain. The point surely is that the current hit and miss system of legal aid funding and aid delivery is not adequately meeting its mark. The taxpayers' legal aid pocket is not a bottomless pit. It is an area which deserves our ongoing attention.

In these recent proposals, the Commonwealth has taken the initiative of targeting responsibility for Commonwealth matters for those needing family law, child support and help with pension and benefit matters. It is time the states and territories were accountable for legal aid delivery for their own law and order matters. The dictates of fairness demand it.

This decision is not about better utilising money, it is about taking that money away. It is a straight budget cut.
As I said, that is from Attorneys‐General who predominantly do not come from this side of politics. In the media release they went on to say:

Now those people will be left without representation by the Commonwealth's budget cut. All the promises before the election of consultation with Legal Aid Commissions, better funding for access to justice and a secure future for Legal Aid have been jettisoned for little more than a budget saving. Legal aid is a social issue and not just a legal measure. Legal aid is provided to assist those people in society who need help.
That is precisely what this argument is about: helping those people who can least defend themselves—something that the people on the government side do not understand.

The annual report of the Legal Aid Commission of Queensland for 1994‐95 shows the number of people who were helped and their income brackets. According to the report, 72.4 per cent of the applicants rely on pensions and benefits for their income; and the average weekly income of pensioners and beneficiaries is $217.74. The report shows that 20 per cent of the applicants had cash or money assets in banks and building societies. What about the other 80 per cent? One can only assume that they had nothing in banks or building societies. The average amount for those who did have assets was $826.

The report shows the housing situation for those people. It tells us that 36 per cent of the applicants rented accommodation at an average weekly rent of $97; only five per cent owned or were purchasing their own homes; and the average weekly mortgage payment was $136. These are the true Aussie battlers. These are the people whom the government pretends to represent. These are the people who are being thrown aside by this savage cut to funding for legal aid.

When you go further into the report, you find that the number of applicants with no income rose from 10 per cent to 15 per cent in 1993‐94. As to the extent of the funding, one only has to look at the extent to which the funding is used throughout Queensland, particularly rural Queensland. The reports lists civil cases as: Bundaberg, 24; Cairns, 10; Ipswich, 9; Maroochydore, 11; Toowoomba, 52; and Townsville, 11. The number of people is not large, but they are people who would be affected by this decision. The report also lists family cases as: Bundaberg, 17; Cairns, 24; Mt Isa, 20; Toowoomba, 47; and Townsville, 39. The numbers, whilst not great, are significant. They are people who find that their backs are to the wall. This is all from a government that pretends to represent the battler. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing a matter of public importance raised by Senator Bolkus, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to honour its pre‐election commitment to maintain funding for legal aid.

I think every single Australian knows by now that the biggest failure of any party to honour a pre‐election commitment was when the Labor government, under Mr Beazley, the then Minister for Finance, promised that the budget was in surplus. When we came to power we found that, rather than the budget being in surplus, it was in fact in deficit by $8 billion. If the Labor Party want to cry crocodile tears about the cuts we have to make, they should have thought about that before they overspent. In fact, they remind me of the spouse who takes the family pay packet to the pub and then complains when the car is repossessed. They say that the family ought to have a car; that the family is entitled to have a car. Sure, the family ought be entitled to have a car, but it can no longer afford it if all the money got spent in the pub.

Similarly, with the Labor Party, over 13 years they virtually bankrupted this country, and we now have to make some very tough decisions. The promise we made before the election was on the basis of the promise by the then Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, with hand on heart, that the budget was in surplus. That clearly was not correct. I will not say that it was a lie because that is unparliamentary, but I think the people of Australia have made their decision as to whether or not the truth was told by Mr Beazley and the Australian Labor Party. We made our promises in good faith on the basis of the Labor Party's promise about the state of the budget. That clearly was not the case.

Time and time again we have these discussions in the Senate about the government not keeping pre-election promises. Then we are told about the devastation being caused within the community because somehow we are unable to match the promises that we made. It is a bit like an arsonist standing by complaining about the water damage being done by the fire brigade, taking no responsibility for his action and for the real damage that has been caused, but standing by saying, `Look at these terrible fire people. In putting out the fire they are causing a bit more water damage.'

If we did not put out the financial fire in this country, there would be no legal aid, there would be no social security for anybody because the totality of this country would be bankrupt. Yet they have the audacity to come into this chamber and suggest that it has nothing to do with them. The cuts that this government has to implement is a direct result of their overspending over a period of 13 years.

I seek to make a few comments in relation to previous contributions. In question time Senator Bolkus spoke about increased lawlessness with cuts to legal aid. I confess that, whilst I was practising full time as a lawyer, I often did legal aid cases in the criminal area. I have to say, quite frankly, that a lot of people got the benefit of technicalities and other matters that let them out of gaol, when some casual observers might say that they should have been in gaol.

If we want to talk about lawlessness, we are really talking about more money for the police rather than legal aid to defend people to keep them out of gaol to commit more lawless acts. I am not quite sure where Senator Bolkus got that terminology from, other than somebody from the legal aid area whose letter I did read. The assertion about lawlessness simply does not make sense. However, I do agree that it is a pity that we do not have enough money to fund legal aid to the extent that we might wish to.

Senator Murray made an emotional plea about deaths in custody of our indigenous people. I would have thought that anybody who wished to partake in this debate would have made themselves aware of the facts. The Aboriginal Legal Service is not funded out of the Attorney‐General's Department but out of the department of Aboriginal affairs. So that was a complete furphy thrown in. It was a good emotional topic to try to latch on to but, as so often is the case with the Australian Democrats, is completely irrelevant to the topic that we are discussing today.

Senator Murray then commented about the cost of justice and this provision of money from legal aid to private firms in the event that we cut legal aid. Possibly he does not understand, but a substantial bulk of legal aid money goes to private firms because private firms, such as the ones I am associated with, do legal aid work on behalf of the legal aid commissions around this country. So it is not to put more money into the hands of private lawyers. In fact, these cutbacks will undoubtedly mean that private lawyers will get less from legal aid. So that argument can also be thrown out and has no substance.

Senator Brown made a very emotional plea about community activists. He talked about how they cannot get money, how they need legal aid and how the big corporations are able to get tax deductibility. Allow me to remind Senator Brown that, when he was up on police charges and was in fact convicted, the Coordinator of the Tarkine National Coalition sent this memo around. It said:

Court defences are very costly and those who place themselves in this position are standing up for the environment and need our fullest support. The best way you can assist is to provide cash donations—any amount, $20 or more, whatever you can spare—to the fighting fund. Please forward your donations either direct to the Tarkine National Coalition or—
and wait for this—
for tax deductibility through the Tasmanian Conservation Trust Inc. marked for the Tarkine campaign.

Honourable senators would be aware that, under the terms of the gift provisions of the income tax law, a body seeking acceptance as a tax deductible environmental organisation must have a policy of not acting as a mere conduit for passing on donations to third parties. So perhaps Senator Brown ought to think again before he comes into this chamber high and mighty about tax deductibility, because he was involved in such a rort courtesy of Mr Peter Sims.

BREAK.PARA: To conclude this debate on behalf of the government, the reality is that the cuts that have to be made are simply as a result of the Labor government's overspending.
