SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 19, page 16 (lines 14 to 16), omit subclause (2), substitute:

(2) The Minister may make a determination reducing an amount that is payable to the State under any provision of this Act in a program year by an amount not greater than the repayable amount, provided that the Minister may not make a determination reducing an amount calculated under section 44 unless, in respect of the relevant State, any of the requirements of Division 2 of this Part have not been complied with.
(13) Clause 44, page 35 (line 9), omit "not greater than", substitute "equal to".

The opposition moves these amendments because they deal with a fundamental problem we see with the legislation. I am glad Senator Harradine is here to participate in this debate, as he normally is conscientious when critical issues arise.

I can understand Senator Vanstone's frustration that she is caught in here at this particular moment while in South Australia the Liberal Party is lining up for a meeting which will change the Premier of that state by 7 or 8 o'clock tonight. It is a pity for South Australia that they are going from Dean Brown to John Olsen. They should just cut out the middle man and go to Joan Hall. She has been running the game there for quite some time. It must be frustrating for you, Mr Temporary Chairman Chapman, and for Senator Vanstone to be caught in here.

As expressed in the second reading debate, we are concerned about this legislation for a number of reasons, one of which is the flood of funds it will allow from one sector to the other. If people are concerned about choice in education, they should be concerned about the level of choice that will remain, as a consequence of this legislation, to those who are, for instance, in the government sector. We must remember that we do not talk here of finite resources. We must also remember that what we are dealing with here is a mechanism which will allow funds to go from one sector to the other.

In the second reading debate, I indicated that some $177 million was our estimation of the level of resources that would go from the government sector to the non‐government sector. The Democrats' figure is some $305 million. Whether it is one or the other, we are talking here of an enormous amount of money going from one sector to the other. The government says that reflects a number of students going from the government sector to the non‐government sector. There would be an allowance for each one of these. Senator Harradine said he was pleased that that allowance was only half of the average cost per student.

The first point to make about that is that a marginal cost is quite different from not only an average cost but also half the average cost. The second point to make is that, in the period of this legislation, we are talking about a lot more students for the government sector as well. Population growth would indicate that there would be more students in the government sector. This legislation will ensure that the level of money that has been available up until now will not be available per student in the government sector.

BREAK.PARA: When you talk about choice and extending choice, you have to recognise here that, as was written to us a couple of days ago by the Australian Council of State School Organisations, `one parent's choice will be another parent's school closure'. That should be of critical concern to all of us.

Let us remember that we are talking about at least $177 million going from the government sector to the non‐government sector by the operation of this benchmark. Let us also remember we are talking about more students in the government sector.

What does that mean? When you have more students and fewer resources per head it is going to impact and it will impact in the traditional ways. It will mean that there will be less choice in terms of curriculum. It will also mean, particularly in rural areas, that governments will have less flexibility to accommodate the direct interests of regions or communities. It is going to impact somewhere and in a way that the students and parents who are in the government sector will be necessarily disadvantaged because of the restrictions placed on funding.

Senator Harradine raised the question of disabled students and how they will be catered for. My understanding is that some 70 per cent of funding for disabled students goes to government schools. If those government schools are going to be left with fewer resources per student and to have almost $200 million milked out of them as a consequence of this benchmark, they will not have as much capacity to accommodate those with specific needs, not only because of reduced resources—and we have to recognise that those with disability do need extra resources—but also because the government is doing away with targeting of specific needs as one of its initiatives in this legislation.

Before the election, the government promised that they would spend $6 million a year more to cater for those disabled students but that has not been delivered. When Senator Vanstone talks about the amount of money that will be spent on disabled students, she is not talking about the increase that they promised before the election. Let us make that very clear. She is talking about continuing levels of funds, but not the increase. When you take into account that you are not increasing funds and are going to have the government sector, which at the moment handles some 70 per cent of the funds for the disabled, cut back severely as a consequence of this legislation—and you are going to have more students—and if you are concerned about disabled students in our school system, you really have to be concerned about this legislation and the way that it opens up blank cheques in terms of some of the unwinding of requirements.

Choice, as Professor Ken McKinnon said, is something that really needs to be taken into account and thought about seriously in the context of finite resources. His report, completed in February this year, debunks the very points that this government is making to justify its abolition of the policy. As he said, the notion of choice in education can be infinitely expanded and the establishment of non‐government schools in any circumstance automatically results in savings to the public purse.

The two arguments used by the government are arguments that just do not hold water when you are talking about finite resources. That is why this government have sought to bury the McKinnon report. That is why they have not taken it into account. That report runs totally counter to the sorts of arguments and ideological inclinations that they are pursuing with this legislation. McKinnon debunked the government's primary arguments. They cannot run away from that. He debunked them to the extent of exposing that you cannot have the degree of choice this government is talking about, given the parameters and the finite resources we are talking about.

It is true that the abolition of the new schools policy formed part of the coalition's pre‐election policy announcements. But what was not explained before the election was how it would be funded, Senator Vanstone. The truth about how it would be funded is another reason why you have been pretty keen to bury the McKinnon report.

The growth of the non‐government sector will be funded by the enrolment benchmark adjustment and that adjustment is a permanent benchmark for the reduction of Commonwealth expenditure on government schools. This will result in some $177 million at least being taken out of the government school sector. The rationale for this extraordinary attack on the state school sector is, as I said earlier, the use of the mechanism of average costs and average costs indicating a saving to the state of $3,400 for each student in the non‐government sector, based on the proportion of public cost, in each case borne by the Commonwealth. You are going to rip $1,700 per capita for all future changes in the balance.

McKinnon found this approach flawed but he was not the only person who found problems with your direction. Most of the state governments before the Senate committee gave evidence to that committee's inquiry about the benchmark.

It is probably best at this stage to place on record all the comments from Mr Christopher Taggart, the Director of Management Accounting at the New South Wales Department of School Education. He told the committee:

The state believes that you will not save at the average. You will not save across the school system entirely based on the average cost of that school system. You will not see a librarian, a head teacher, a principal, a deputy principal, the ancillary staff, my position, the Director General's position or state officer's position, changed. You will only ever see marginal changes in classroom numbers . . . Also, you will generally only see changes in the number of students in a particular class—one, two, three, four, depending on the school. You will not see whole schools disappear. You will not see the whole subject areas disappear. Therefore, to take all the school system, including the admin and executive structure of the school, as well as the state infrastructure and bend, delete or change it in any way is a nonsense. You will only see the change at the margins. Therefore, the DEET analysis—
this government's analysis—
is fundamentally flawed.

Our amendment would prevent the government using this legislation to apply its enrolment benchmark adjustment. We believe that if you are going to make those adjustments and flick money from one sector to the other, you still have the option of doing that. How ever, we would rather you did it up-front with public debate and when you front the states and territories across the table at the Premiers Conference. That is the honest way to do it. It should not be done through the use of some benchmark formula which year by year ensures that money is siphoned off from one section to the other. We want you to be up-front and not use the sleight of hand that this formula will present. We are concerned here with the impact of this agenda, particularly because your formula and benchmark are flawed. The formula does not take into account the continuing, growing needs of the government sector.

Senator Vanstone talked about an ERC meeting. The reference I made in this debate yesterday was to the leaked minutes of a coalition Expenditure Review Committee meeting on 3 and 4 June 1991, where the current Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp)—

TALK.START.PARA: —Half a decade ago.

—It was half a decade ago, but Dr Kemp was commissioned to do the work then and he is now the minister. What was he asked to do then? He was asked to be bound by the current imperatives. He noted that the coalition sought to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools. For five or six years, the objective of the coalition and this minister has been to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools. They have given no real consideration to the impact of that.

BREAK.PARA: It was also agreed at that meeting that Dr Kemp would report back to the committee on non-government schools and whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and reductions in untied grants. That is exactly what you have done now. A long held ideological fixation of this minister and this government has been to reduce funding to government schools and give the extra funding to non-government ones. We had this debate over state aid years ago. We argue in opposition that you can pick up the McKinnon recommendations, change the formula and accommodate some of those problems that Senator Vanstone talked about earlier, but you should not throw away the baby with the bathwater, which is exactly what you are doing here. That is the real problem we have here. For those reasons, I move these amendments together.

If senators such as Senator Harradine are really concerned about targeting people with disabilities and specific needs, this legislation does not provide that for them. This funding proposal is about a reduction in aid to government schools. This is legislation that lumps together former equities aimed at specific groups of educationally disadvantaged young people. You are now lumping them all together and blurring the focus of those programs. In respect of that, Keith Staples, the president of the Australian Council of State School Organisations, made it very clear to all of us in the Senate by letter this week, when he said:

A further concern with this bill is that the broadbanding of programs diminishes the capacity to target disadvantage. ACSSO particularly regrets the loss of the disadvantaged schools program and the students at risk program.

There are concerns. If you want to pick up some of the problems of the past regarding non-government school funding, there are mechanisms available to do that. That would essentially require a minor amendment after picking up the recommendations of McKinnon. I would rather pick up the recommendations of McKinnon than the ideological fixation of your former shadow ministry and now ministry, which is driven to push money from one sector to another and, as in so many other circumstances, divide the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment. We have been very clear in our approach to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996, which is that we do not endorse the funding mechanism behind the legislation. I take this opportunity to put on the record my response to Senator Abetz this morning and to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), the minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), a little earlier. I did not say that Jewish schools were fundamentalist. I merely quoted from their submission. I was very careful to say yesterday in my speech on the second reading debate that the Democrats could have lived with the abolition of the new schools policy provided that it did not proceed at the expense of the public schools sector. We do not have a problem with new non-government schools starting up. We have a problem with, firstly, allowing those schools to start up in a completely unplanned, ad hoc and unrestricted manner and, secondly, funding those schools by taking money off state schools.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very clear that, without any restrictions, the number of new schools that seek to start operation will be small. They will be much smaller in number than those state schools in Victoria, for example, which are currently being forced to close down. It is quite clear that a number of them will come from fundamentalist religious backgrounds. That is the reason I made that comment.

I simply asked the Senate to consider whether it was good policy to fund those sorts of schools and that size of school—remembering that one of these schools might be set up with just one student—at the expense of mainstream public education. I believe that the answer to that question should be no. If Senator Abetz supports that proposition, he is seriously out of touch with the vast majority of Australians and he is certainly seriously out of touch with Australian parents with children in both government and non-government schools.

I will turn to the amendments. The Democrats would have preferred to see the minister withdraw the abolition of the new schools policy and the enrolment benchmark adjustment for one year. That was the basis of our second reading amendment. There would be 12 months for a proper inquiry and 12 months for a public debate. I remind the Senate that there were just two days for a hearing of the committee on this matter. Even the peak bodies complained that they had had very little time to prepare submissions. They also complained that the data available to them was incomplete.

BREAK.PARA: The peak bodies complained that there was inadequate information. They complained about having no time to get back to their own groups, whether it was other bodies or school councils. It was very clear that the level of public debate on this issue was low and that people were not fully aware of the implications. I do not think the government was either.

In our view, it would have been a much more appropriate and responsible approach to have delayed those elements of the bill until this could have taken place. It is hard to imagine how much wider those concerns could be when you have teachers and parents from state schools, teachers and parents from private schools, state governments, education academics and Catholic and independent schools all saying that when they finally came to grips with the information it was found to be incorrect.

I suggest that surely any reasonable minister who was genuinely concerned about this portfolio would sit down and have a rethink. Unfortunately, the minister has not had that rethink. He has not agreed to further consultation and has not agreed to defer these changes for that 12-month period. The Democrats believe that we do not have any alternative but to support the opposition's amendments, which would at least seek to restrict the operation of the proposed enrolment benchmark adjustment and to ensure that clearly defined planning processes are in place.

It is very obvious from listening to the speakers in the second reading debate that they still do not understand how the EBA works. I want to take some time yet again today to go through that mechanism. I want to refer to a table which was included in the report of the committee. It is on page 67, for those who have a copy of it here. This table is based on the department's own figures. It is based on the figures of projected enrolments over the next four years. It is based on the government's own figures in relation to funding mechanisms and it also calculates how that enrolment benchmark adjustment works.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the government projects that 23,524 students will not be in state government schools at the end of that four-year period. It is very important to note that. This is a change from the previous estimate that the government gave during the budget period, which was, as Senator Bolkus mentioned, a small increase of 4,000 students. These are the figures we are all working from and these are the figures from which I draw my suggestion that $305 million will come out of the state system.

A total of 23,524 students will exit the state system. If you look at that table you will also see a figure of 94,551, which is the total number of students over and above the current numerical level in the private sector. So we have the state sector losing 23,524 students and the non-government schools increasing their numbers by 94,551.

You will clearly see from the enrolment benchmark adjustment calculations that $1,712 does not simply follow those 23,000 students who exit the state system. That $1,712 is applied to the figure which is over and above the current benchmark. That figure becomes $73,669 by the year 2000. The EBA does not simply allow the $1,712.50 to follow the students out of the state sector and into the private sector.

It is a different mechanism which draws $1,712 for every new student in the private sector. That is not the same thing because, overall, the total enrolments will increase by something like 61,000. That increase, which is mostly going into the private sector, will be paid for by deductions to the state.

The reason why I did not concentrate on questions such as broadbanding and disability services is that this is such a fundamental question. It seems to me that very few people have followed this debate and have followed that mechanism. It is absolutely crucial because if this enrolment benchmark adjustment is continued over time as we go beyond the year 2000, the cumulative effect of this would be that eventually the government would be taking so much away from the state sector as a result of the EBA that it would have no money left going back into the state system. By my calculations, we reached that point by something less than 50 per cent in state schools and 50 per cent in the private sector.

Clearly, we are not looking at those figures but I think we need to recognise that a mechanism such as this is going in that kind of direction. I am not suggesting that we are going to get to that point. I am simply saying that the higher the proportion of private school students to government school students, the higher this penalty is applied to the states. It is very important that everybody recognises this.

I think it is interesting that in her speech at the end of the second reading stage, the minister pointed to my choice of the quote from the Jewish day schools and one or two other fairly minor points, but did not address this key question. She has not at any stage challenged my assertion that, based on the government's own projections, $305 million will be withdrawn from the state system.

I go back to the figures that Senator Bolkus was talking about—the figures that came out at the time of the budget, which showed that the government increased its enrolments by some $4,000. I think the figure was $3,900‐odd. Under those circumstances, because the private sector would have increased its proportion and it would have increased its numbers numerically, by my calculations there would have been a cut of $270 million. That is with the state sector maintaining its current level—its current actual numbers. It is losing its proportion, yes, but it is maintaining its numbers and the cut would still have been $270 million from the state sector.

I hope I have explained that. I am happy to go through that again. As I said, I think it is absolutely fundamental. I also think it is unfair, and this is the reason why the Democrats do not support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few questions that I would like the minister to address, if she will. They go to some of these basic issues on the operations of the EBA. Minister, could you explain to the committee how the EBA will work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The EBA, the enrolment benchmark adjustment, has been explained to you on a number of occasions, but let me give you a quick run through it again. It is designed to ensure that money in a sense follows the students so that, where there is a shift of students, there would be a shift of money. It is an adjustment to the grants to the states and territories as a consequence of the movement in the ratio of non-government students to government students from the 1996 benchmark. You would understand that any movement of government students to the non-government sector represents an average saving of about $3,400 per student to the states and territories. Perhaps before I go on, you might do me the courtesy of indicating whether you accept even that.

—Minister, I do not accept that, because the issue goes to the matter of whether it is at marginal or average cost. But that is not the point that I think we are seeking to address at this stage. I am trying to get a clear understanding from the government as to how this EBA works. You might also be able to explain to the committee whether or not it is possible for the government sector to maintain its number of students and the private sector to increase its number of students over the forward estimates period and that, therefore, under this EBA arrangement, the amount of money going to the government sector would decline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me come back to the point that I was trying to get you to come to; that is, whether you accept simply that, when a government student shifts to a non-government school and you maintain funding as though that student was still there at the government school, that is a saving to the state or territory. If you want to avoid that, that is fair enough.
—I have answered that question for you, Minister.

—I do not believe you have. Nonetheless, I have the floor now—I am happy to sit down and let you have another go. I will move on in any event. The proportion of enrolments in non-govern ment schools has moved from about 24.4 in 1983 to 29 in 1995. The aggregate of the annual savings to the states since 1983 because of that shift is estimated to be about $3 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The enrolment benchmark adjustment seeks to split those savings fifty‐fifty with the states. It reduces the potential for cost shifting between levels of government. It adjusts the share of government school general recurrent grants to states by approximately 50 per cent of the gain that would accrue to state governments as a result of the enrolment drift from the government sector to the non-government sector. The states still retain the remaining 50 per cent gain.

I will give you an example of the operation of the EBA. If the census showed an increase in the non-government enrolment share at the end of 1997, the states would gain on average $3,400 per student. That is their saving. The effect of the EBA is that the states would retain $1,700 and $1,700 would be deducted from the Commonwealth's grants to the states. If the census showed no change in relative enrolment shares or an increase in the government share, the EBA would not be triggered. For example, if a state experienced a 0.4 per cent increase in the share of non-government enrolments—up from 29 per cent in 1996 to 29.4 per cent in 1997—and that equated to a drift of 5,000 students, the EBA would be triggered. If the average net saving in the state was $3,400 per student, the total saving would be $17 million. Under such a scenario, the Commonwealth would retain $8.5 million and the state would retain $8.5 million.

The total projected Commonwealth funding for all schools is an increase of $3.7 billion over the next four years. That comes through SPPs, EBAs and FAGs. You asked what would happen if the numbers stayed the same—I think that is what your point is—in government schools and the proportion changed because there was an increase in non-government sector enrolments. I just point out that your whole question is prefaced on an assumption on your part that, where there is an increase in enrolments, government schools will not be able to have a share of them because they are not performing well enough to attract the parents' choices. That is your assessment. That is the scenario you are working on.

You ask then would the funding decrease. Let me make it plain to you: total funding to schools, government and non-government, will increase. But if the enrolment benchmark is triggered, that necessarily means that some of the money that would otherwise have been kept by the states for their government schools would go the other way. I think that is the whole purpose of it. It amazes me that you have not yet come to grips with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the question again because it is obvious that I am having trouble expressing myself clearly. If the number of government students remains the same but the proportion changes, is it not the case under your proposal that there will be less money for government schools as a result of the operation of the EBA?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, equally I may have some trouble expressing myself, so let me put it to you as plainly as I can. I am telling you that in such circumstances funding to government schools would increase in any event. But, of course, the EBA would trigger a shift. I think I know what you are confusing or where our messages are mixing—and the government is not hiding from this. You know full well what the EBA does if it is triggered and shifts money from one sector to another. But you are asking me to say therefore that total funding falls, and it does not. Total funding for the government sector increases and the EBA is just a very small part of that funding.

—Minister, I take it you are saying the answer to the question is yes, that it is triggered. I draw your attention to answer No. 52, which was given by your department in answer to the question that I asked before the estimates committee. That answer went to the issue of the forward estimates in real terms for all the outyears in regard to general recurrent grants, capital grants, government targeted programs and joint targeted programs in government schools and in the non‐government sector. Does that answer not indicate that your department has told the Senate that the amount of money available to government schools will decline under this budget?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will have to ask your indulgence for a minute. The questions that I have got go up to 48 and then start again at one. If someone else would like to make a contribution while I get to question 52, I will come back to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put some direct questions to the minister. I have already made mention of a number of calculations that have been made. I want to ask specifically: do you agree with the calculation on your own figure—these are the figures produced at the time of the budget—that on an increase of 4,000 students in the state sector, the state school budget would be decreased by $270 million? That is a direct question. I have put this kind of question often enough for it to be directly answered. If the answer is yes—I believe it must be—how can you then say that the funds follow the student?

SPEECH.PARA: We heard quite a lot about total overall budgets increasing, but it seems to me that that misses the point. The question that we all want to know the answer to and want you to confirm is: even though the state government may lose only a small amount, may increase its numbers or may keep the numbers the same, regardless of that the amount of money which comes out of the state system is disproportionate to that—that is, it does not follow the student across. I will repeat that again: do you agree with the calculation that, on your own figures, on an increase of 4,000 students state schools would lose $270 million?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I will be back with you in a minute.

—I will ask the question again. The figures that I mentioned earlier—the figures that were produced at the time of the budget—showed that there would be an increase of just under 4,000 students in state schools but that there would still be a loss of $270 million to the state budget because of the enrolment benchmark adjustment and because of the proportion shifts. If that is the case—if you will confirm that figure—how can you continue to say that the funds follow the student? Will you not then agree that they do not; that in fact the enrolment benchmark adjustment has the disproportionate effect and, I would say, the punitive effect of penalising the state system?
—I am just getting an answer on that for you, Senator.

—I have another question, which relates to the later calculations. They are the ones that I quoted earlier which showed that although state schools would lose 23,000 students the private sector would increase. It is all in the table here. All I am asking for is confirmation. I have already had this from the department, but I would like you, Minister, to say so in committee. I would like confirmation that, on the basis of the government's own projections, the $305 million and the $239,000 would be deducted from the state sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are just coming to the second question, Senator. Can I put it to you this way when we say that the funds follow the student: because the proportion of non‐government enrolments changes, we therefore think that because the money changes it means it does follow the student. Rather than perhaps come back and just quote figures, could you indicate why you think that is an inappropriate assertion to make?

—I think it is inappropriate if we take the hypothetical situation of there being no numerical change. It is hypothetical because we are talking about a four‐year period. Would you mind doing the calculations which would show the effect of there being no numerical change to state government enrolments. What I am talking about therefore is the private sector in fact picking up on the new enrolments. The government expects there to be something like 60‐odd thousand new enrolments over the next four years. I think it is unreasonable for you to then say, `Well, you know, there is some sort of reason why those states are not performing if this is the case.' I think that is an argument that may well be relevant in terms of this whole question, but it is not relevant when we come to the question of the effect of the EBA. I would like you to concentrate on that, and tell us what happens in terms of a funding shift in the event that the state sector maintains its absolute numbers. What happens to funding under those circumstances?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Allison is basically asking me the same thing that Senator Carr has just asked me. I believe I made it clear from my answer to him that the numbers stay the same but the proportion changes. You have picked up on the remarks that I made to him, but I think it is a pretty non-supportive proposition to put for government schools. You have suggested that, where there are increases in enrolments because of population change, the government sector will get none of them. That is the assumption that your question is based on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite right that, if those new students all shift to non-government schools, certainly there should be an adjustment towards the non-government schools because they are taking all the extra students. Of course there should be, and there would be, but only as it relates to the EBA. Senator, I should counsel you against getting this out of perspective. The EBA is a small part of the total funding. If you do not accept the EBA, you are saying that, irrespective of parents making the choice that they want their children to have a different education, irrespective of the fact that parents might choose to send their kids to the local Christian school, total funding as it exists today should stay the same for ever and a day.

You are suggesting that we should keep funding government schools, despite what may be continuing declining enrolments, and fund them at the same level. You are saying that we should provide no incentive whatsoever for government schools to appreciate the consequences of losing students—no incentive at all: just keep performing as they are. You know full well that there are plenty of government schools that are doing really well. They are schools that people want to get their kids into. That is the choice they want to make.

It is important to reflect that choice in funding. If all the new students go to other schools, there should be some adjustment to reflect that. Of course there should be. I am at a loss to understand why you do not think that should be the case. I am equally at a loss to understand why it is that this relatively speaking minor adjustment—because it is a fifty‐fifty sharing of the windfall gain to the states—is something that you treat as the whole funding package.

You comment as if funding to government schools is going to fall. If you set up an enrolment benchmark adjustment which is designed to reflect changes in student loads, and someone has a reduction in the proportion of their load, obviously vis-a-vis that benchmark adjustment it will be a negative if they get a lesser proportion. But to pretend that that somehow is a large part of the funding and to ignore the fact that in any event, on the calculations that we have done—which show an increase to non-government schools—government schools get more perplexes me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister to confirm the figures in this table: that is, the $305 million based on the government's own projections. I think it is important to get on the record that the government accepts that that is the case. I would also like to ask a more fundamental question. Why does the government not simply fund new enrolment places in the private sector? Why does it feel the need to make this shift on the basis of a proportion? Why not simply say, if 23,000 students come out of the state sector, let us remove the per capita grant that those students attract, which is around $406 on average per student. Let us just remove that for the 23,000 students and fund those new places in the private schools.

SPEECH.PARA: That would seem to me to be a straightforward, fair and logical way of calculating how the funding should flow. I think the Senate needs to have an explanation as to why the government thinks this enrolment benchmark adjustment is necessary at all. Why is it contingent on the issue of proportion in the first place? What does that have to do with the business of funding schools?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What it has to do with the business of funding schools is that there is a bucket of money for schools. If I can rephrase the proposition that you are putting at the moment, you are saying that, irrespective of the choices parents make, the government should keep the proportions of funding exactly as they are now. That is basically the proposition that you are making when there is a limited capped program.

SPEECH.PARA: What you are saying is, `Leave it as it is. Don't take any notice of the fact that parents are making alternative choices. Don't shift your funding to follow the choices that parents make. Ignore that.' That is what you are saying. We disagree with that. This is what politics is all about. We have a genuine policy disagreement. We believe that, if parents want to make different choices, the funding should reflect that. It should not be a funding arrangement that stays the same irrespective of a demonstrated choice by parents.

So we have set an adjustment that reflects the choices made by parents. We think that is appropriate. You do not. I do not think that I am going to change your mind, and you are certainly not going to change mine. We simply have a policy disagreement. There is nothing dreadful about that. That is what this place runs on basically. You are not going to agree with it, and I understand that.

Equally, we are not going to move away from the fact that we think it is fair that funding reflects the choices made by parents. You cannot continue to do two things. You cannot continue to try to block parents making those choices, as the previous government's new schools policy did. We have schools operating without Commonwealth funding because the previous government tried to stop people setting up new schools when they wanted to go their own way. That is just not appropriate.

BREAK.PARA: We have a policy disagreement here. I think sometimes when you have a disagreement in principle about what ought to happen, no amount of debate will change anybody's mind. You understand how it works, I understand how it works, and I think Senator Carr understands how it works. What I am seeking to do is avoid any pretence that Senator Carr is intellectually limited today and does not understand how it works. He does understand how it works. I am sure he does. He does not like it.

We have a policy disagreement. There is nothing particularly special about that. Those in the Labor Party often have different views from those of us in the Liberal and National parties. The Democrats have different views at different times. I have disagreed with Senator Harradine in the past and I have agreed with him in the past. On matters of principle, no amount of debate is basically going to change people's minds. So let us stop pretending that you do not understand how this works. You do understand how it works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator, I understand that very well. What I want you to do is admit that, in fact, it is not a case of students taking the money when they go across from the state sector to the private sector. I would really like to hear that come from your mouth.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up on a comment that you made. Funding, in my view, does already reflect the choice made by parents. I am simply asking you why it is that we need this complex enrolment benchmark adjustment when another mechanism which funded that choice in private schools could do just as well. I think what you are telling me is that, at the end of the day, the government does not want to change its bottom line. So there will be an increase in private school students, and they will cost the government much more than its per capita funding grant to the states. Therefore, that bottom line, if it is to be kept the same, has to be paid for through the state school budget.

I will come back to my first question, because I really would like confirmation of this. The $305,239,000, on the government's own figures, will be the effect of the enrolment benchmark adjustment over four years. The department will probably say, `No, that's not true because the enrolment benchmark adjustment is shifted out 12 months. It is not calculated until the 12-month period.' I am interested in the effect of, over four years, the operation of the enrolment benchmark adjustment. I understand that it shifts out 12 months but, nevertheless, I am interested in the effect of that four-month period. I ask you to confirm that the effect of that enrolment benchmark adjustment over that four‐year period will be $305 million and $239,000 based on the government's own projections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, all I can say that is useful is that, as you well know, what happens to the funding as a consequence of the EBA—and we are just talking about the EBA—is a function of the enrolments that happened at the end of each year. We can speculate on any number of little tables you can produce, and it would be futile. We are arguing about the principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand, as you rightly indicate, the department does have some concern with some variation along that table. So let us stick to the substantial principles here. The principle is that, if there is a big shift, we think funding should follow that. We do not think the states should be able to lump the costs onto the Commonwealth and make that enormous saving. We think it is fair enough. We are prepared to split it fifty-fifty. You just keep ignoring the choices made by parents as if, for some reason, this shift that has been happening is not something the government need reflect in any way and can just go on ignoring. We do not agree with you, Senator. We have a different view. We think that, if parents want to shift their children, the funding should reflect that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a fanciful question. It is a very important one, so I will put it to you again. I have not made these figures up. It is not something I have dreamt up myself. I have used actual figures. I have used the government's own actual budget figures and the government's own actual enrolment figures. I would like an answer to that question. I think it is reasonable for us to say, `Well, what is the impact of the government's figures?' Then we can understand the substantial issues and we can understand what it is that the government intends. It is philosophy and intention that we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: So I will ask you that question again. In the event that the enrolments as projected by the government are those as were given to the education committee hearing not so many weeks ago, is it true to say that, in line with those shifts in enrolments, $305 million and $239,000 would be deducted from the states? I hear your arguments about sharing half the savings and so forth but there is, nevertheless, an important principle to understand in terms of how this enrolment benchmark adjustment works. So I ask you again to confirm or deny that that figure is an accurate one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, let me put it to you this way. You can add up. You can do the calculations. There is no dispute, as I understand it—though I am just informed—as to your capacity to use a calculator. What I am saying is that you can work out a whole range of scenarios and you, quite rightly, identify that the forward estimates do not go out as far as you choose to project. You can make whatever projections you like. All I can tell you is that you can add up. You can calculate properly. You can use a calculator.

—I am sorry, but I really have to press this point because they are not my projections. They are in no way my projections. They are the projections of the department. I am happy for you to revise those. This is already the second revision we have had of these projections. I prefer the first scenario, but these are not my figures. They are simply an arithmetical calculation and, as you say, I have used my calculator to do that. I want you to indicate that the implications of those projections and the implications of the enrolment benchmark adjustment actually mean that figure at the end of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will give you the same answer I gave you before. You can add up. You do understand how it works. You can put any table before me, and I will tell you the same thing. If you can get the calculations right, I will tell you that you are capable of adding up, and you are.
—Is she right or wrong?
—It is simple. I have given her the answer.
—So she's right. We can assume she's right.
—I have given her the answer. It is perfectly simple.

—Minister, I wonder if I could get an answer to a question that I put to you before. Is it the case that answer No. 52—which was given to me in response to a question I placed on notice in the estimates hearings—indicates that total government expenditure by the Commonwealth for government schools between the period 1995-96 to the out‐years 1999-2000 reflects a cut in Commonwealth funding to government schools?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have with me now volume 1 of the additional information received by the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee at page 36. I am just making sure I understand what you are asking me. You are asking me: is the `Total Government' figure for 1995-96 larger than the figure for 1999-2000—that is, does it show a decrease? I think that is your question. Clearly, it does. You understand of course that is in 1996 prices. You understand that it is not in out term prices and you understand that it does not include the FAGs.

—That is exactly the point, Minister. You have been claiming all over this country that this government will be providing more resources for government schools when your own department has indicated to the Senate that there are fewer resources in terms of specific purpose payments measured in 1996 dollars. Your own department has indicated that there is a cut. In fact, that cut is quite dramatic, particularly if you look at the years from 1996 to the year 1999‐2000. The cut in fact is of the order of $87 million. This is quite inconsistent with the statements that you have been making. Therefore, is it not the case that you have clearly misled the Senate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have raised a couple of times in this chamber your comments that you have used in the past where you have seen the benefit and the appropriateness of looking at funding for schools in terms of SPPs and FAGs. You acknowledge this table does not include the FAGs for starters. You must acknowledge that, because it does not. You can raise all the discussion you like as to that table, provided you are fair enough to indicate that it does not include the FAGs. You understand that; I am sure you do. Additionally, the point that I have consistently made is that the SPPs and the FAGs show an increase.

—You assert that it shows an increase. Would you also acknowledge that this is an entirely hypothetical proposition since the Commonwealth has no control over the spending of FAGs by the states? Would you acknowledge that as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge suggestions—I am not sure if they were made by you, Senator, but I am sure they were made by some people on your side—that the states were now going to walk away from education. As I have indicated in an answer today—it may have been to Senator Allison; someone put this proposition to me; or perhaps it was here—on the best indications we have, the states are actually increasing their spending.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, you are right. They could. Lots of things could happen. But what does the best information we have available at the moment show us? It shows an increase. So you can go out and scaremonger all you want, but, as I am informed, the best information available to us showed about a six per cent increase in funding on education by the states. You have recognised the reality. What are we meant to do? Faint with excitement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you also acknowledge that, in the answer from your department through the estimates process to questions Nos 9 and 10, the total amount of extra resources going to schools over the four‐year period is some $128 million and that that is as a result of specific budget measures? You would acknowledge that, would you not?
—All schools?
—And that is all schools, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in answer to your questions 9 and 10, I am advised that the table that you are referring to on page 22 is in fact an underestimate of the total money that will be flowing to schools. What it is designed to show is simply a summary of the net effect of the 1996-97 changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point, is it not, Minister: that it shows the net effect of 1996-97 budget measures, which is the basis on which this bill is being debated—not on some hypothetical notion and not on some mystical figure that you put forward in terms of possible expenditure by state governments based on possible allocations of moneys and based on FAGs which are not in real dollars but which are calculated on inflationary dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: We must presume that the answers provided to the Senate by your own department are accurate. We must presume that. We cannot presume that your answers are accurate, but I think it would be a reasonable conclusion to draw that the department would seek to get it right. It says that the net effect of the 1996‐97 budget measures, the basis for this bill, is the $128 million extra all up, and that is expenditure for schools in all sectors—private and public. However, the answer on question No. 52 reflects a decline, particularly between 1996-97 and 1999‐2000, of some $87 million for the public sector.

So, while we have an increase in total of $128 million, and we have a decline for the public sector of $87 million, is it not therefore logical to conclude that the proportion of money going to the private sector is dramatically increased, to the tune, in fact, of nearly $200 million? So the proportions are actually growing for the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not think you can compare the two totals. I think you agreed that one is in out-term prices and one is in 1996 prices. We are not comparing like with like here. Of course, you are looking simply at implemented measures; you are not looking at policy decisions made, for example, for continuation of supplementation. You do not factor that in. You are just making an assessment on the negatives. That is what they are. No-one has tried to hide anything in that respect at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, the point is you were asked a direct question about the net effect of the budget measures. Your department indicates that the net effect of the budget measures is $128 million all up. You can try to confuse it by talking about whether or not these statements are in out‐year prices or constant prices, but I understand that both figures are in constant prices. This figure relates to the total budget cuts for your department of $4.3 billion over the four years. But, in terms of school contributions to your total budget programs over the four years, there is only an additional $128 million going into the schools as a result of these budget measures.

SPEECH.PARA: So the answers you have been giving about an extra $2.3 billion are totally misleading. You have constantly, deliberately and repeatedly misled the Senate as to the result of this government's decisions in regard to spending for schools. You are seeking to mislead the Senate as to the effect of this EBA and the consequences of this EBA for the operations of the public education system in this country. You are seeking to present a picture which is not accurate, which does not reflect what is actually occurring.

What you are in fact presenting to this Senate is an acknowledgment that the total number of students in government schools can remain constant but they will still lose money under this proposal. There will be a shift. Your budget figures indicate that in every possible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the minister, Senator Carr, during your contribution you said that the minister had deliberately misled the Senate. That is unparliamentary, and I would ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw anything that is regarded as unparliamentary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have no reason to assume whatsoever that anything my department has prepared in answers to you in estimates is inaccurate. There has been the occasion when I have been given incorrect advice by the department, and on each of those occasions the appropriate steps have been taken. But it does not lead me to conclude that any information offered now is incorrect. I acknowledge your gracious assertion that you do not assume it is incorrect either.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pointed out to you the difference between the two tables. One is in 1996 prices and one is in out-term prices. I have indicated to you that the table on page 22 does not, for example, quantify the implicit ticks given to retaining things like supplementation and all of those things. You do not want an acknowledgment of that.

The bottom line, Senator, is that you understand how this works and that we have an in‐principle disagreement. We can talk about it until we are blue in the face. We just have different in-principle views. You happen to think that, if there are more students and they all choose to go to non-government schools, that funding should stay the same, that we should just ignore the choices of parents in that respect. We have a different view.

BREAK.PARA: You believe the enrolment benchmark adjustment is inappropriate. You would say that, irrespective of a declining proportion for government schools—or a declining proportion for non-government schools—funding should stay the same. We have a different view. That is what we are talking about here. You do understand how this works. I am sure you do. I am sure Senator Allison understands how it works, too.

Clearly, you want to go to your constituency, which you see at the moment as being government schools, and say, `This is unfair. You should be able to retain whatever moneys you were otherwise thinking you were going to get, irrespective of falling enrolments. We tried in the Senate a falling proportion of enrolments. If you keep the same numbers you have got today, and in the year 2010 you still have the same numbers and all the other kids have gone somewhere else, you come to us, because we will ensure that you keep the same money.' We think that is ridiculous. We want to have a mechanism that recognises that.

It is at the edge of funding. To you and I, this is a lot of money. Of course it is. But across funding for schools, it is a small adjustment to make. You do not think that that adjustment should be made. You think that in the year 2010, if they have the same number of students as today, things should be left as they are. I presume that is the argument you are raising. You are saying `if they have the same number of students', despite the fact that in the year 2010 we might have a lot more students.

I am working on your assumption—not mine—that all of it goes to non-government schools. That is a harsh assumption on your part, but it is probably made simply for the purposes of debate to keep the argument simple. Perhaps you do assume that they would go to non-government schools. If you do assume that all the growth goes to non-government schools, your argument is that there should be no adjustment.

In principle, we have a disagreement. We think parents want greater choice. They have demonstrated that. Despite the restrictive new schools policy of the previous government, parents were still determined to make alternative choices for their children. They did so sometimes without Commonwealth funding. We think that is wrong. We think the funding has to reflect the choices the parents want to make. But let us not pretend that this EBA is the totality of funding. It is after all an adjustment, and that is all it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, surely you would acknowledge that the current administrative arrangements for the distribution of Commonwealth moneys for recurrent purposes is on a per capita basis. Do you acknowledge that that is the case?
—Yes.
—Minister, if you acknowledge that it is the case that there is already a mechanism that funds the schools on the basis of parental choice, as you would like to term it, why then do we need the EBA?

SPEECH.PARA: Why is the government of New South Wales wrong when it says that, on the basis of the cost indications that it has made, these alleged savings are not able to be realised and that there will be a cost to the state of New South Wales, for every two per cent shift in enrolments, of between $20 million and $30 million? While you are there, Minister, can you tell us why the government of Queensland says that the cost to that state, given the differences in demography and various other things, is $16 million? While you are at it, Minister, what do you say to the government of Western Australia when it, too, says this is an inappropriate mechanism to calculate the funding of schooling or the economics of schooling?

PARA.BREAK: Perhaps you can tell us why the Tasmanian government is wrong when it says that the calculations that you have made are misguided and are conceptually wrong. What about the Northern Territory government and the Australian Capital Territory government? The only government in Australia that has not said this is, of course, the beloved Victorian government, which is setting about closing another 113 schools this year, which you say reflects an increase in expenditure in that state on education, and which follows the 300 schools that they have closed, which presum ably you will also indicate reflects an increase in expenditure in that state.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it, Minister, that every state in the Commonwealth with the exception of Victoria has indicated your calculations are wrong and, quite specifically, by very large sums of money, that you have made a fundamental flaw in your calculations on the proposition that costs can be averaged rather than calculated at the marginal rate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —After 12 years in the federal parliament, it is no surprise to me whatsoever that a state which looks like it has been caught out cost shifting and faces a change as a consequence of that, naturally, argues its case. Of course they are going to. We have a federal system and there is always argy‐bargy between the states and the Commonwealth. It probably works the other way, if the states ever think they have successfully caught the Commonwealth out. I have yet to meet a state minister—or, for that matter, a person—who welcomes the identification that they are no longer going to get funding that they used to get in the past. Of course, they complain. Of course, they use every bit of political rhetoric they possibly can.

SPEECH.PARA: They come along and say, `You've got your figures wrong, we want more money.' Of course they do. That is to be expected. No state says, `Gee, you've cottoned on that we are saving money every time kids leave government schools and shift to non‐government schools, that we've been happily doing a bit of cost shifting. Now that you've found it out, I feel very guilty. Heavens, let us offer you more money.' That is not going to happen, Senator Carr. If, in the duration of your time here, your party returns to government—and if you expect to stay here for a long time, I suppose that will happen; it comes in cycles—if you expect people to come along and push you out of the way in order to give you money back, you are in for a big shock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I come back to the EBA. I note, Minister, that you are saying that it is a small matter, that this calculation is nothing in relation to the overall funding picture. But I come back to what Senator Harradine said in the second reading debate. He said that where a student moves from one system to another, the savings go with them and that the principle of money following the students was a reasonable one.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I agree with that. That is why I suggested earlier that if there are new students going into the private sector, why not fund them on a per capita basis, just as we do now? And why not fund the government school students on their per capita basis, just as we do now? What you are really saying, I think, is that there are going to be 61,000 new enrolments but that the government is not prepared to fund them, that it is going to have to find the money elsewhere and that the enrolment benchmark adjustment is finding that money through the state system.

I come back to this because it is fundamentally important. Senator Harradine says that it is the reason why he voted against my amendment which would have allowed us at least 12 months to get this matter of the dollars, the mechanism and whether or not it was reasonable sorted out. Senator Harradine was of the view that the principle of money following the student is reasonable, and I totally agree with that. But I hope that today's debate has shown that it is not about the principle of the money following the student; it is the principle of the money following the proportion of students. The two are very, very different.

We have already demonstrated that if the government schools—and you may or may not think this is reasonable—maintain their numbers, that is, that no students went across to the private sector, there was no matter of money following students who pack their bags and went into the private sector, the state systems would still lose money. That is the point of this whole debate.

PARA.BREAK: I come back to that calculation—$305 million, which is the result to the state system of the figures that have been prepared by the government. As I say once again, I did not make them up. They are the government's own figures. It is not reasonable, Minister, for you to say that we are scaremongering or that we are making up figures at will. The govern ment expects that 23,000 fewer students will be in the state system. It expects that 94,000 more students will be in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I might disagree with those figures, and I probably would, and they are, at best, guesses, I imagine. Nevertheless, they are what we have to go on. They are official figures. They are what the government has produced and, at the end of the day, what they mean is that, for that loss of 23,000 students in the state sector, there will be a penalty of $305 million. If you divide the $305 million by that figure of 23,000, even if you spread it over the four‐ year period, we do not get $1,712.50. We get something like three times that amount.

I think you have got to be honest, Minister, and explain, particularly to Senator Harradine, who expects that this is a reasonable proposition. He expects that the principle of money following the student is reasonable, and I think so, too. What we have here is something quite different. The enrolment benchmark adjustment is not reasonable. It is not fair and it is skewed to take money, because the federal government would need to fund the private sector at a higher rate.

We all know that the average contribution, by per capita recurrent grants, is more than $2,000 for the private sector and, on average, around $400 to the government sector. That is per capita. I realise that FAG grants make up the difference to the states—we all understand that—but the point is that the government is going to have to wear a much higher cost. I think it is about $180 million more by the time we get to the year 2000, on the basis of these figures, because of that higher per capita grant that it makes to the private sector. The government is funding the expansion of the private sector and it has to take those dollars away from the state system in order to protect its bottom line. That is the crunch of this whole debate.

I think it is quite irrelevant to be talking about the FAGs and about how much the states are going to contribute to add to that spending on education because, Minister, you do not know that any more than I do. We do not know what the state governments are going to spend on education between now and the year 2000. We have already heard that there is no evidence that there will be an increase. And anyway, it is irrelevant. It is irrelevant to this debate, which is primarily about the enrolment benchmark adjustment.

I think what we have heard from you today is an admission—you do not actually come out and say it—that the money does not follow the student, that it is the money following the proportion. That, I suggest to you, is unfair and unreasonable. It is a penalty being applied to the state sector.

I really think it is time the government re-examined this whole question and found a more equitable solution to its bottom line. If it is going to have to fund this expansion in the private sector, it ought to look at how it is going to do that. I suggest that to take that money out of the state sector and, I suppose, develop a funding mechanism which does that in this very devious way and for you to suggest that somehow it is the fault of the states that this is all happening is quite unreasonable. I really do not know how much more I can say on this issue to make it clear to senators. What is absolutely clear is that the money does not follow the student and that is a most unreasonable position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not say that this is the fault of the states. I do not say that at all. The reason parents make the choices they make is a matter for them. There may be reasons quite unrelated to state government decisions that encourage or motivate parents to make a different choice. So I do not say that this is the fault of the state governments at all. If you have got that impression, you have got the wrong impression. If I have given you the wrong impression, I hope that I have now made it clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The point was made, as I have indicated to you, that this focus on the EBA is, I think, out of perspective. I have indicated that to you. I say that it is a relatively small adjustment being made. You paraphrase that and say that I say it is nothing. I do not say that it is nothing, but I do say that it is small. On our rough calculations—that is not to the last decimal point—it would be about three per cent if you looked at it as a proportion of SPPs. If you did as Senator Carr did in 1995 when he wanted to sing the praises of the then government and you put SPPs and FAGs together, you would see that it is less than one per cent. That is what we are focusing on here: of the total—that is, SPPs and FAGs—it is an adjustment that on our calculations is less than one per cent. That is what I was seeking to highlight by saying, `Do not get this EBA out of perspective at all.' I think I indicated and said that, relative to the total funding, it is a small thing. Relative to the total funding, it is a very small thing.

I just come back to the point, Senator Allison: you and I have a different policy view here. We believe that if parents are going to choose for their children to be students in non-government schools and if that shift keeps happening, we should not allow the states to engage in that cost shifting and just expect to keep the same amount of money. So a relatively small adjustment mechanism has been set up—the EBA. As a proportion of SPPs and FAGs, we calculate that that will be just under one per cent. You think that is inappropriate. I do not, and the government does not think it is inappropriate. I just wanted to highlight for you exactly what the proportions are as we calculate them. According to our calculations, they are about three per cent of SPPs. But when you look at the total funding picture, it is less than one per cent. That is what we are talking about now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a question before concerning the government of New South Wales. Minister, could you please explain to the committee why it is that the government of New South Wales claims that this measure will cost them between $20 million and $30 million for every two per cent shift in enrolments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in front of me the DEETYA submission to the committee. At page 16, paragraph 3.1.3, dealing with the effects of the enrolment benchmark adjustment on New South Wales, states:

BREAK.PARA: New South Wales data, quoted in the second reading speech debate and in the New South Wales Department of Training and Education submission No. 13 to the committee—
which you were on—
indicated that the impact of the enrolment benchmark adjustment would be a net cost to the government rather than a reduced level of savings.
That is what you are asking me about. It goes on:

The New South Wales government's advice to DEETYA shows that with 21,000 fewer students in the government sector or a shift of two per cent enrolments; firstly, the state has a reduced funding requirement of some $37.2 million; and, secondly, the state incurs additional non‐government per capita grant costs of $3.7 million; and, thirdly, that the state loses $9 million Commonwealth per capita grants funding; and, fourthly, the state loses $35.8 in funds as a result of the benchmark adjustment.
In summary, you probably have the table in front of you so it might be easier to move on. The DEETYA submission goes on to say:

The analysis, however, is flawed and incorrect. The savings figure of $37.2 million simply reflects the reduced direct costs of teacher salaries. The analysis is inadequate in not recognising the saving to the state in reduced requirement for school executive staffing, school and non-school administrative staffing, as well as general school running costs and utility costs. For this reason, the saving is significantly understated.
It goes on to say:

The analysis also included a notional reduction in Commonwealth funding of $9 million. This amount represents general recurrent funds which would have been provided by the Commonwealth for the 21,000 students who had left the government sector. As general recurrent funding is provided on a per capita basis, the New South Wales government could only expect to be paid in respect of the actual numbers of students in government schools in the state and would never have been entitled to the $9 million shown or referred to above. Accordingly, that amount should be disregarded.
So it goes on. You have had an explanation. If you are not satisfied with it, I am sorry. Nonetheless, that is the explanation that is offered.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell)—by leave—proposed:
That after the consideration of the government document today, government business may be further considered till 7.20 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate that the opposition will agree to this proposition. We do so on the basis that we have now set a substantial pattern of offering time up for the consideration of legislation. I trust that is acknowledged and that we now have I think a very substantial period of time that has been offered by the opposition for the consideration of government business.
